editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: She wou'd if she cou'd, A COMEDY.
Acted at His HIGHNESSE the DUKE of YORK'S THEATRE.
LONDON, Printed for H. Herringman, at the Sign of the Blew Anchor in the Lower walk of the New Exchange. 1668.

list.item: Sir Oliver Cockwood & Sir Joslin Jolley, Two Country Knights.
Mr. Courtall & Mr. Freeman, Two honest Gentlemen of the Town.
Ariana & Gatty, Two young Ladies, Kinswomen of Sir Joslin Jolley's.
Mrs. Sentry, My Lady Cockwoods Gentlewoman.
Mrs. Gazette & Mrs. Trinket, Two Exchange-women.
Mr. Rake-hell, A Knight of the Industry.
A Servant belonging to Mr. Courtall.

div.head: SCENE I.
A Dining-Room.
div.stage: Enter Courtall and Freeman, and a Servant brushing Courtall.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: SO, so, 'tis well: let the coach be made ready.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: It shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Well, Franck, what is to be done to day?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Faith, I think we must e'ne follow the old
Trade; eat well, and prepare our selves with
A Bottle or two of good Burgundy, that our
Old acquaintance may look lovely in our Eyes;
For, for ought as I see, there is no hopes of new.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Well! this is grown a wicked Town, it was
Otherwise in my memory; a Gentleman
Should not have gone out of his Chamber,
But some civil Officer or other of the Game
Wou'd have been with him, and have given him
Notice where he might have had a course or
Two in the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Truly a good motherly woman of my acquaintance
T'other day, talking of the sins of the times,
Told me, with tears in her Eyes, that there are a
Company of higling Rascals, who partly
For themselves, but more especially for some
Secret friends, daily forestall the Markets;
Nay, and that many Gentlemen who formerly had
Been Persons of great worth and honour, are of late,
For some private reasons, become their own
Purveyors, to the utter decay and disencouragement
Of Trade and Industry.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I know there are some wary Merchants,
Who never trust their business to a Factor;
But for my part, I hate the Fatigue, and had
Rather be bound to back my own Colts, and man
My own Hawks, than endure the impertinencies
Of bringing a young Wench to the Lure.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, there is a Gentlewoman below desires to
Speak with you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Ha, Freeman, this may be some lucky
Adventure.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: She ask'd me, if you were alone.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: And did not you say Ay?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I told her, I would go see.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Go, go down quickly, and tell her I am.
Franck, prithee let me put thee into this
Closet a while.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why, may not I see her?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: On my life thou shalt have fair play, and
Go halfs, if it be a purchase that may with
Honour be divided; you may over-hear all:
But for decency sake, in, in man.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Well, good Fortune attend thee.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Mrs. Sentry, this is a happiness
Beyond my expectation.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I hope your Lady's come to Town?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Sir Oliver, my Lady, and the whole Family:
Well! we have had a sad time in the Country;
My Lady's so glad she's come to enjoy the freedom
Of this place again, and I dare say longs to have
The happiness of your company.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Did she send you hither?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh no, if she should but know that I did such a
Confident trick, she wou'd think me a good one.
I faith; the zeal I have to serve you, made me
Venture to call in my way to the Exchange,
To tell you the good news, and to let you know our
Lodgings are in Iames-street at the Black-Posts,
Where we lay the last Summer.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Indeed it is very obligingly done.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: But I must needs desire you to tell my Lady,
That you came to the knowledge of this by some
Lucky chance or other; for I would not be discovered
For a world.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Let me alone, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir Oliver Cockwood, Sir, is come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: O Heaven! my Master! my Lady, and my self
Are both undone, undone—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, why did you not tell him I was busie?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: For Heavens sake, Mr. Courtall, what shall
I do?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Leave, leave trembling, and creep into the
Wood-hole here.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Sir Oliver Cockwood!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Honest Ned Courtall, by my troth I think
Thou tak'st me for a pretty Wench, thou
Hug'st me so very close and heartily.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Only my joy to see you, Sir Oliver, and to
Welcome you to Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Methinks, indeed, I have been an age absent,
But I intend to redeem the time; and how, and how
Stand Affairs, prithee now? is the Wine good?
Are the Women kind?
Well, faith, a man had better be a vagabond
In this Town, than a Justice of Peace in the
Country: I was e'ne grown a Sot for want
Of Gentleman-like recreations; if a man
Do but rap out an Oath, the people start
As if a Gun went off; and if one chance
But to couple himself with his Neighbours
Daughter, without the help of the Parson of
The Parish, and leave a little testimony of
His kindness behind him, there is presently
Such an uproar, that a poor man is fain to
Fly his Country: as for drunkenness, 'tis true,
It may be us'd without so and all, but the Drink
Is so abominable, that a man would for bear it,
For fear of being made out of love with the vice.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I see, Sir Oliver, you continue still your old
Humour, and are resolv'd to break your sweet
Lady's heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: You do not think me sure so barbarously
Unkind, to let her know all this; no, no, these
Are secrets fit only to be trusted to such
Honest Fellows as thou art.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Well may I, poor Sinner, be excus'd, since
A Woman of such rare beauty, such incomparable
Parts, and of such an unblemished
Reputation, is not able to reclaim you from
These wild courses, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: To say the truth, she is a Wife that no man
Need be asham'd of, Ned.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I vow, Sir Oliver, I must needs blame you,
Considering how tenderly she loves you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, the more is her misfortune and mine
Too Ned: I would willingly give thee a pai▪
Of the best Coach-Horses in my Stable, so
Thou could'st but perswade her to love me
Less.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Her virtue and my friendship sufficiently
Secure you against that, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I know thou wert never married; but has it
Never been thy misfortune to have a Mistress
Love thee thus entirely?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: It never has been my good fortune, Sir Oliver▪
But why do you ask this question?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Because then, perchance, thou might'st have
Been a little sensible what a damn'd trouble it is.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: As how, Sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Why look thee, thus: for a man cannot be
Altogether ungrateful, sometimes one is oblig'd
To kiss, and fawn, and toy, and lye fooling an hour
Or two, when a man had rather, if it were not for
The disgrace sake, stand all that while in the Pillory
Paulted with rotten Eggs and Oranges.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: This is a very hard case indeed, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: And then the inconvenience of keeping
Regular hours; but above all, that damn'd fiend
Jealousie does so possess these passionate Lovers,
That I protest, Ned, under the Rose be it spoken,
If I chance to be a little prodigal in my expence
On a private Friend or so, I am call'd to so strict
An account at night, that for quietness sake I am
Often forc'd to take a Dose of Cantharides to
Make up the sum.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Indeed, Sir Oliver, every thing consider'd,
You are not so much to be envy'd as one may
Rashly imagine.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, a pox of this tying man and woman
Together, for better, for worse! upon my conscience
It was but a Trick that the Clergy might have
A feeling in the Cause.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I do not conceive it to be much for their
Profit, Sir Oliver, for I dare lay a good wager,
Let 'em but allow Christian Liberty, and they
Shall get ten times more by Christnings,
Than they are likely to lose by Marriages.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Faith, thou hast hit it right, Ned; and now
Thou talk'st of Christian Liberty, prethee let us
Dine together to day, and be swingingly merry,
But with all secrecy.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I shall be glad of your good company, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I am to call on a very honest Fellow, whom
I left here hard by making a Visit, Sir Iossin, Iolly,
A Kinsman of my Wifes, and my Neighbour in the
Country; we call Brothers, he came up to Town
With me, and lodgeth in the same house; he has
Brought up a couple of the prettiest Kinswomen,
Heiresses of a very good Fortune: would thou
Hadst the instructing of 'em a little;
Faith, if I am not very much mistaken,
They are very prone to the study of the
Mathematicks.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I shall be beholding to you for so good an
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: This Sir Ioslin is in great favour with my
Lady, one that she has an admirable good
Opinion of, and will trust me with him
Any where; but to say truth, he is as arrant
A sinner as the best of us, and will boggle at
Nothing that becomes a man of Honour.
We will go and get leave of my Lady;
For it is not fit I should break out so soon
Without her approbation, Ned.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: By no means, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Where shall we meet about an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: At the French-house or the Bear.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: At the French-house by all means.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Would thou could'st bring a fourth man.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: What think you of Franck Freeman?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: There cannot be a better—well—
Servant, Ned, Servant, Ned!

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir Oliver.
Mrs. Sentry!
Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Ay, Ay! you may venture to bolt now.
Oh Heavens! I would not
Endure such another fright.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Come, come, prethee be compos'd.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I shall not be my self again this fortnight;
I never was in such a taking days of my life.
To have been found false, and to one who to
Say truth, has been always very kind
And civil to me; but above all, I was concern'd
For my Lady's Honour—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Come, come—there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Ah! Mr. Courtall, you do not know Sir Oliver
So well as I do, he has strange humours sometimes,
And has it enough in's Nature to play the
Tyrant, but that my Lady and my self awe him
By our Policy.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Well, well, all's well; did you not hear
What a taring Blade Sir Oliver is?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Ah! 'tis a vile dissembling man; how fairly
He carries it to my Lady's face! but I dare not
Discover him for fear of betraying my self.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Well, Mrs. Sentry, I must dine with 'em,
And after I have enter'd them with a Beer-glass
Or two, if I can I will slip away, and pay my
Respects to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You need not question your welcome,
I assure you, Sir—your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your Servant, Mrs. Sentry, I am very sensible
Of this Favour, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I am proud it was in my pow'r to oblige you,
Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Freeman! come, come out of thy hole; how
Hast thou been able to contain?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Faith much ado, the Scene was very pleasant;
But above all, I admire thy impudence,
I could never have had the face to have wheadl'd
The poor Knight so.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Pish, Pish, 'twas both necessary and honest;
We ought to do all we can to confirm a
Husband in the good opinion of his Wife.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Pray how long, if without offence a man may
Ask you, have you been in good grace with this Person
Of Honour? I never knew you had that
Commendable quality of secrecy before.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: You are mistaken, Freeman, things go not
As you wickedly imagine.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why, hast thou lost all sense of modesty?
Do'st thou think to pass these gross wheadles on
Me too? come, come, this good news should make
Thee a little merrier: faith, though she be an old
Acquaintance, she has the advantage of four or five
Months absence. 'Slid, I know not how proud
You are, but I have thought my self very spruce
E're now in an old Suit, that has been brush'd
And laid up a while.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Freeman, I know in cases of this nature thou
Art an Infidel; but yet methinks the knowledge
Thou hast of my sincere dealing with my
Friends should make thee a little more confiding.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: What devilish Oath could she invent to
Fright thee from a discovery?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Wilt thou believe me if I swear, the preservation
Of her Honour has been my fault, and not hers?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This is something.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Why then, know that I have still been as
Careful to prevent all opportunities, as she has been to
Contrive 'em; and still have carried it so like a
Gentleman, that there has not had the least suspicion
Of unkindness: she is the very spirit of impertinence,
So foolishly fond and troublesom, that no man above
Sixteen is able to endure her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why did you engage thus far then?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Some conveniences which I had by my
Acquaintance with the Sot her Husband, made
Me extraordinary civil to her, which presently
By her Ladiship was interpreted after the manner
Of the most obliging women: this Wench came
Hither by her Commission to day.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: With what confidence she deny'd it!

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Nay, that's never wanting, I assure you;
Now is it expected I should lay by all other
Occasions, and watch every opportunity to wait
Upon her; she would by her good will give her
Lover no more iest, than a young Squire that
Has newly set up a Coach, does his only pair of Horses.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Faith, if it be as thou say'st, I cannot much
Blame the hardness of thy heart: but did
Not the Oafe talk of two young Ladies?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Well remembred, Frank, and now I think
On't, 'twill be very necessary to carry on my business
With the old one, that we may the better have
An opportunity of being acquainted with them.
Come, let us go and bespeak dinner, and by the
Way consider of these weighty affairs.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Well, since there is but little ready money
Stirring, rather then want entertainment,
I shall be contented to play a while upon Tick.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: And I, provided they promise fair, and we find
There's hopes of payment hereafter.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Come along, come along.

div.head: SCENE II.
Sir Oliver Cockwood's Lodging.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: 'Tis too late to repent: I sent her, but yet
I cannot but be troubled to think she stay's so long;
Sure if she has so little gratitude to let him, he has
More honour then to attempt any thing to the
Prejudice of my affection—Oh—Sentry, are you come?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh Madam! there has been such an accident!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Prithee do not fright me, Wench—

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: As I was discoursing with Mr. Courtal, in came
Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh!—I'm ruin'd—undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You'l still be sending me on these desperate
Errands.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I am betray'd, betray'd—by this
False—what shall I call thee?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Nay, but Madam—have a little patience—

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I have lost all patience, and will never
More have any—

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Do but hear me, all is well—

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Nothing can be well, unfortunate Woman.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Mr. Courtall thrust me into the Wood-hole.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: And did not Sir Oliver see thee?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: He had not the least glimpse of me—

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Dear Sentry—and what good news?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: He intends to wait upon you in the
Afternoon, Madam—

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I hope you did not let him know I sent you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: No, no, Madam—I'le warrant you I did every
Thing much to the advantage of your Honour.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Ah Sentry! if we could but think of some
Lucky plot now to get Sir Oliver out of the way.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You need not trouble your self about that,
Madam, he has engag'd to dine with Mr. Courtall at the
French-house, and is bringing Sir Ioslin Iolly to get
Your good Will; when Mr. Courtall has fix'd 'em
With a Beer-glass or two, he intends to steal
Away, and pay his Devotion to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Truly he is a Person of much Worth
And Honour.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Had you but been there, Madam, to have
Over-heard Sir Oliver's Discourse, he would have
Made you bless your self; there is not such another
Wild man in the Town; all his talk was of
Wenching, and swearing, and drinking, and tearing.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, Sentry, I know he'll talk of
Strange matters behind my back; but if he be not
An abominable Hypocrite at home, and I am not a
Woman easily to be deceived, he is not able
To play the Spark abroad thus, I assure you.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Oliver, and Sir Joslin, Sir Joslin singing
sp.l: My dearest Dear, this is kindly done of thee
To come home agen thus quickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Nay, my Dear, thou shalt never have any
Just cause to accuse me of unkindness.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Sir Ioslin, now you are a good man, and
I shal trust you with Sir Oliver agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Nay, if I ever break my word with a Lady,
I will be deliver'd bound to Mrs. Sentry here,
And she shall have leave to carve me for a Capon.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Do you think I have a heart cruel enough
For such a bloody execution?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Kindly spoke i'faith, Girl, I'le give thee
A Buss for that.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Fy, fy, Sir Ioslin, this is not seemly in my
Presence.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: We have all our failings, Lady, and this is
Mine: a right bred Grey-hound can as well forbear
Running after a Hare when he sees her, as I can
Mumbling a pretty Wench when she comes in my way.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I have heard indeed you are a parlous man,
Sir Ioslin.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: I seldom brag, Lady, but for a true Cock of
The Game, little Ioslin dares match with the best of 'em▪

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Sir Ioslin's merry, my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, if he should be wicked, I know
Thou art too much a Gentleman to offer an injury
To thine own dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Faith, Madam, you must give my
Brother Cockwood leave to dine abroad to day.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I protest, Sir Ioslin, you begin to make
Me hate you too; well, you are e'ne grown as bad
As the worst of 'em, you are still robbing me of
The sweet Society of Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, come, your Discipline is too
Severe, i'faith Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Sir Oliver may do what he pleases, Sir,
He knows I have ever been his obedient Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Prithee, my Dear, be not angry, Sir
Ioseph was so earnest in his invitation, that none
But a Clown could have refus'd him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, we dine at my Uncle Sir
Ioseph Iolly's, Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Will you be sure now to be a good
Dear, and not drink, nor stay out late?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: I'le engage for all, and if there be no
Harm in a merry Catch or a waggish Story—
Ha, ha! Sly-girl and Mad-cap, are you got up?
I know what you have been meditating on;
But never trouble your heads, let me
Alone to bring you consolation.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We have often been beholding to you,
Sir; for every time he's drunk, he brings us
Home a couple of fresh Servants.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, farewel my Dear, prithee do not
Sigh thus, but make thee ready, visit, and be merry▪

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I shall receive most satisfaction
In my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, come along, Brother: farewel
One and all, Lady and Sly-girl, Sly-girl and Mad-cap,
Your Servant, your Servant—

div.stage: Ex. Sir Oliver and Sir Joslin singing▪

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: to Sentry aside. Sentry, is the new Point I
Bought come home, and is every thing in a readiness?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Every thing, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Come, come up quickly then, Girl, and
Dress me.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Dost not thou wonder, Gatty, she should be
So strangely fond of this Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Well, if she does not dissemble, may I still
Be discover'd when I do; didst thou not see how▪
Her Countenance chang'd, as soon as ever their
Backs were turn'd, and how earnestly she whispered
With her Woman? there is some weighty affair
In hand, I warrant thee: my dear Ariana, how
Glad am I we are in this Town agen.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: But we have left the benefit of the fresh
Air, and the delight of wandring in the
Pleasant Groves.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Very pretty things for a young Gentlewoman
To bemoan the loss of indeed, that's newly come to a
Relish of the good things of this world.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Very good, Sister!

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Why, hast not thou promis'd me a thousand
Times, to leave off this demureness?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: But you are so quick.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Why, wou'd it not make any one mad to hear
Thee bewail the loss of the Country? speak
But one grave word more, and it shall be my daily
Prayers thou may'st have a jealous Husband, and then
You'le have enough of it I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: It may be, if your tongue be not altogether
So nimble, I may be conformable; But I hope
You do not intend we shall play such mad Reaks
As we did last Summer?

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: 'Slife, do'st thou think we come here to be
Mew'd up, and take only the liberty of going from our
Chamber to the Dining-Room, and from the
Dining-Room to our Chamber again? and like a
Bird in a Cage, with two Perches only, to hop
Up and down, up and down?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Well, thou art a mad Wench.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Would'st thou never have us go to a Play
But with our grave Relations, never take the air but
With our grave Relations? to feed their pride,
And make the world believe it is in their power
To afford some Gallant or other a good bargain?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: But I am afraid we shall be known again.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Pish! the men were only acquainted with
Our Vizards and our Petticoats, and they are wore
Out long since: how I envy that Sex! well! we
Cannot plague 'em enough when we have it in
Our power for those priviledges which custom
Has allow'd 'em above us.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: The truth is, they can run and ramble here,
And there, and every where, and we poor Fools
Rather think the better of 'em.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: From one Play-house, to the other Play-house,
And if they like neither the Play nor the Women,
They seldom stay any longer than the combing
Of their Perriwigs, or a whisper or two with a
Friend; and then they cock their Caps, and out they
Strut again.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: But whatsoever we do, prithee now let us
Resolve to be mighty honest.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: There I agree with thee.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: And if we find the Gallants like lawless
Subjects, who the more their Princes grant,
The more they impudently crave.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: We'll become absolute Tyrants, and deprive
'Em of all the priviledges we gave 'em—

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Upon these conditions I am contented to trail
A Pike under thee—march along Girl.

div.head: SCENE I.
The Mulberry-Garden.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: WAs there ever a couple of Fops better match'd
Than these two Knights are?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: They are Harp and Violin, Nature has so
Tun'd 'em, as if she intended they should
Always play the Fool in Consort.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now is Sir Oliver secure, for he dares not go
Home 'till he's quite drunk, and then he grows
Valiant, insults, and defies his sweet Lady;
For which with Prayers and Tears he's forc'd
To feign a bitter repentance the next morning.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: What do we here idling in the Mulberry-Garden?
Why do not we make this visit then?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now art thou as mad upon this trail, as if
We were upon a hot scent.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Since we know the bush, why do we not start
The Game?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Gently, good Franck; first know that the laws
Of Honour prescrib'd in such nice cases, will not
Allow me to carry thee along with me; and next,
Hast thou so little wit to think, that a discreet
Lady that has had the experience of so much humane
Frailty, can have so good an opinion of the constancy
Of her Servant, as to lead him into temptation?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Then we must not hope her Ladiship shou'd
Make us acquainted with these Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Thou may'st as reasonably expect, that an old
Rook should bring a young Snap acquainted
With his Bubble; but advantages may be
Hereafter made, by my admission into the Family.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: What is to be done then?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Why, look you, thus I have contriv'd it:
Sir Oliver, when I began to grow resty, that he
Might incline me a little more to drunkenness,
In my ear discover'd to me the humour of
His dear friend Sir Ioslin: he assur'd me, that
When he was in that good natur'd condition,
To requite their courtesie, he always carried
The good Company home with him, and
Recommended them to his Kinswomen.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Very good!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now after the fresh air has breath'd on us
A while, and expel'd the vapours of the Wine
We have drunk, thou shalt return to these
Two Sots, whom we left at the French-house,
According to our promise, and tell 'em, I am a
Little stay'd by some unlucky bus'ness, and
Will be with 'em presently; thou wilt find 'em
Tir'd with long fight, weak and unable to observe
Their Order; charge 'em briskly, and in a moment
Thou shalt rout 'em, and with little or no damage
To thy self gain an absolute Victory.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Very well!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: In the mean time I will make my visit to the
Longing Lady, and order my business so
Handsomly, that I will be with thee again immediately,
To make an Experiment of the good humour of
Sir Ioslin.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Let's about it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Tis yet too early, we must drill away a little
Time here, that my excuses may be more probable,
And my persecution more tolerable.

div.stage: Enter Ariana and Gatty with Vizards, and pass nimbly over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ha, ha—how wantonly they trip it! there is
Temptation enough in their very gate, to
Stir up the courage of an old Alderman:
Prithee let us follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I have been so often balk'd with these Vizard-
Masks, that I have at least a dozen times
Forsworn 'em; they are a most certain sign
Of an ill face, or what is worse, an old
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: The truth is, nothing but some such weighty
Reason, is able to make women deny themselves
The pride they have to be seen.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: The Evening's fresh and pleasant, and yet
There is but little company.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Our Course will be the better, these Deer
••• not herd: come, come man, let's follow.
〈…〉 I find it is a meer folly to forswear any
〈…〉 does but make the Devil the more
〈…〉 temptation.

div.stage: Enter Women again, and cross the Stage.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Now if these should prove two men of War
That are crusing here, to watch for Prizes.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Would they had courage enough to set upon
Us; I long to be engag'd.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Look, look yonder, I protest they chase us.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Let us bear away then; if they be truly valiant
They'le quickly make more Sail, and board us.

div.stage: The Women go out, and go about behind the Scenes to the other Door.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, how fleet they are! whatsoever faults
They have, they cannot be broken-winded.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Sure, by that little mincing step they
Shou'd be Country Fillies that have been breath'd
At Course a Park, and Barly-Break: we shall
Never reach 'em.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I'le follow directly, do thou turn down the
Cross-walk and meet 'em.

div.stage: Enter the Women, and after 'em Courtal at the lower Door, and Free, at the upper on the contrary side.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: By your leave, Ladies—

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: I perceive you can make bold enough
Without it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Your Servant, Ladies—

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Or any other Ladys that will give themselves
The trouble to entertain you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Slife, their tongues are as nimble as their heels.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Can you have so little good nature to dash
A couple of bashful young men out of countenance,
Who came out of pure love to tender
You their service?

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: 'Twere pity to baulk 'em, Sister.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Indeed methinks they look as if they never
Had been slip'd before.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Yes faith, we have had many a fair course
In this Paddock, have been very well flesh'd,
And dare boldly fasten.

div.stage: They kiss their hands with a little force.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Well, I am not the first unfortunate woman
That has been forc'd to give her hand, where
She never intends to bestow her heart

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Now, do you think 'tis a bargain already?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Faith, would there were some lusty earnest
Given, for fear we should unluckily break
Off again.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Are you so wild that you must be hooded thus?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Fy, fy, put off these scandals to all good Faces.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: For your reputations sake we shall keep 'em
On: 'slife we should be taken for your Relations,
If we durst shew our Faces with you thus
Publickly.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: And what a shame that would be to a couple
Of young Gallants▪ methinks you should blush
To think on't.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: These were pretty toys, invented, first, meerly
For the good of us poor Lovers to deceive
The jealous, and to blind the malicious; but
The proper use is so wickedly perverted,
That it makes all honest men hate the
Fashion mortally.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: A good Face is as seldom cover'd with a Vizard-
Mask, as a good Hat with an oyl'd Case:
And yet on my Conscience, you are both
Handsome.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Do but remove 'em a little, to satisfie a foolish
Scruple.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: This is a just punishment you have brought
Upon your selves, by that unpardonable
Sin of talking.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: You can only brag now of your acquaintance
With a Farendon Gown, and a piece
Of black Velvet.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: The truth is, there are some vain fellows
Whose loose behaviour of late has given
Great discouragement to the honourable proceedings
Of all vertuous Ladies.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: But I hope you have more charity, than
To believe us of the number of the wicked.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: There's not a man of you to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: What a shame is it to your whole Sex,
That a Woman is more fit to be a Privy-
Councellour, than a young Gallant a Lover?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: This is a pretty kind of fooling, Ladies, for
Men that are idle; but you must bid a
Little fairer, if you intend to keep us
From our serious bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Truly you seem to be men of great
Imployment, that are every moment ratling from
The Eating-Houses to the Play-Houses, from the
Play-Houses to the Mulberry-Garden, that
Live in a perpetual hurry, and have little
Leisure for such an idle entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Now would not I see thy face for the world;
If it should but be half so good as thy humour,
Thou would'st dangerously tempt me to doat
Upon thee, and forgetting all shame, become
Constant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I perceive, by your fooling here, that wit and
Good humour may make a man in love with
A Blackamore. That the Devil should contrive
It so, that we should have earnest bus'ness now.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Wou'd they wou'd but be so kind to meet us
Here again to morrow.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: You are full of bus'ness, and 'twould but
Take you off of your employments.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: And we are very unwilling to have the sin to
Answer for, of ruining a couple of such
Hopeful young men.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Must we then despair?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: The Ladys you are going to, will not be so
Hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: to Free. On my Conscience, they love us, and
Begin to grow jealous already.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Who knows but this may prove the luckier
Adventure of the two?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Come, come, we know you have a mind to
Meet us: we cannot see you blush, speak it out
Boldly.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Will you swear then, not to visit any other
Women before that time?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Not that we are jealous, but because we would
Not have you tir'd with the impertinent
Conversation of our Sex, and come to us dull
And out of humour.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Invent an Oath, and let it be so horrid
'Twould make an Atheist start to hear it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And I will swear it readily, that I will not
So much as speak to a woman, 'till I
Speak to you again.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: But are you troubl'd with that foolish
Scruple of keeping an Oath?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: O most religiously!

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: And may we not enlarge our hopes upon a
Little better acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: You see all the freedom we allow.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: It may be we may be intreated to hear a
Fiddle, or mingle in a Country Dance, or so.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Well! we are in too desperate a condition
To stand upon Articles, and are resolv'd to
Yield on any terms.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Be sure you be punctual now!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Will you be sure?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Or else may we become a couple of credulous
Coxcombs, and be Jilted ever after.
—Your Servants, Ladys.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: I wonder what they think of us!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: You may easily imagine; for they are not of
A humour so little in fashion, to believe the best:
I assure you the most favourable opinion they can
Have, is that we are still a little wild, and stand in
Need of better manning.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Prithee, dear Girl, what dost think of 'em?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Faith so well, that I'm asham'd to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Wou'd I had never seen 'em!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Ha! Is it come to that already?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Prithee, let's walk a turn or two
More, and talk of 'em.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Let us take care then we are not too particular
In their commendations, lest we should discover
We intrench upon one anothers inclinations,
And so grow quarrelsom.

div.head: SCENE II.
Sir Oliver's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Dear Madam, do not afflict your self thus
Unreasonably; I dare lay my life, it is not want
Of devotion, but opportunity that stays him.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Ingrateful man! to be so insensible
Of a Ladies passion!

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: If I thought he were so wicked, I should
Hate him strangely—but, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Do not speak one word in his behalf,
I am resolv'd to forget him; perfidious Mortal,
To abuse so sweet an opportunity!

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Hark, here is some body coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Peace, he may yet redeem his Honour.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: starting. Mr. Courtall, for Heav'n sake
How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Guided by my good Fortune, Madam—
Your Servant, Mrs. Sentry.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Sir; I protest you made
Me start too, to see you come in thus unexpectedly.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I did not imagine it could be known
I was in Town yet.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Sir Oliver did me the favour to make me
A Visit, and dine with me to day, which brought
Me to the knowledge of this happiness, Madam;
And as soon as I could possibly, I got the
Freedom to come hither and enjoy it.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You have ever been extream obliging, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: 'Tis a worthy Gentleman, how punctual
He is to my directions!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Will you be pleas'd to repose, Sir?
Sentry, set some Chairs.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: With much difficulty, Madam, I broke
Out of my Company, and was forc'd by the
Importunity of one Sir Ioslin Iolly, I think they
Call him, to engage my Honour I would
Return again immediately.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You must not so soon rob me
Of so sweet a satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: No consideration, Madam, could take
Me from you, but that I know my stay at this
Time must needs endanger your Honour; and how
Often I have deny'd my self the greatest satisfaction
In the world, to keep that unblemished, you
Your self can witness.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Indeed I have often had great tryals
Of your Generosity, in those many misfortunes
That have attended our innocent affections.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Sir Oliver, Madam, before I did perceive
It, was got near that pitch of drunkenness,
Which makes him come reeling home, and
Unmanfully insult over your Ladiship; and how
Subject he is then to injure you with an unjust
Suspicion, you have often told me; which makes
Me careful not to be surpris'd here.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Repose your self a little, but a little,
Dear Sir: these vertuous Principles make you worthy to be
Trusted with a Ladies Honour: indeed Sir Oliver
Has his failings; yet I protest, Mr. Courtall, I love
Him dearly, but cannot be altogether unsensible
Of your generous passion.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, I am a very passionate Lover!
Indeed this escape has only given me leisure
To look upon my happiness.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Is my Woman retir'd?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Most dutifully, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Then let me tell you, Sir—yet we
May make very good use of it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now am I going to be drawn in agen.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: If Sir Oliver be in that indecent condition
You speak of, to morrow he will be very submissive,
As it is meet for so great a misdemeanour; then
Can I, feigning a desperate discontent, take
My own freedom without the least suspicion.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: This is very luckily and obligingly
Thought on, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Now if you will be pleas'd to
Make an assignation, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: To morrow about ten a clock in the
Lower walk of the New Exchange, out of which
We can quickly pop into my Coach.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: But I am still so pester'd with my Woman,
I dare not go without her; on my conscience
She's very sincere, but it is not good to trust our
Reputations too much to the frailty of a Servant.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I will bring my Chariot, Madam,
That will hold but two.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: O most ingeniously imagin'd, dear Sir! for
By that means I shall have a just Excuse to give her
Leave to see a Relation, and bid her stay
There till I call her.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: It grieves me much to leave you so soon,
Madam; but I shall comfort my self with the
Thoughts of the happiness you have made me hope for.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I wish it were in my power eternally
To oblige you, dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, sweet Sir.
Sentry—why Sentry—where are you?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Here, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: What a strange thing is this! will you
Never take warning, but still be leaving me alone
In these suspicious occasions?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I was but in the next room, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: What may Mr. Courtall think of my
Innocent intentions? I protest if you serve me
So agen, I shall be strangely angry: you should
Have more regard to your Lady's Honour.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: If I stay in the room, she will not speak
Kindly to me in a week after; and if I go out, she
Always chides me thus: this is a strange infirmity
She has, but I must bear with it; for on my
Conscience, custom has made it so natural,
She cannot help it.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Are my Cousins come home yet?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Not yet, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Do'st thou know whither they went
This Evening?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I heard them say they would go take
The Air, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Well, I see it is impossible with vertuous
Counsel to reclaim them; truly they are so careless
Of their own, I could wish Sir Ioslin would remove
'Em, for fear they should bring an unjust
Imputation on my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Heavens forbid, Madam!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your Servant, Cousins.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: How have you spent the cool of the
Evening?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: As the custom is, Madam, breathing the
Fresh Air in the Park and Mulberry-Garden.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Without the Company of a Relation,
Or some discreet body to justifie your reputations
To the world—you are young, and may be yet
Insensible of it; but this is a strange censorious Age,
I assure you.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Hark! what Musick's this?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I'le lay my life my Uncle's drunk, and hath
Pickt us up a couple of worthy Servants,
And brought them home with him in Triumph.

div.stage: Enter the Musick playing, Sir Oliver strutting, and swaggering, Sir Joslin singing, and dancing with Mr. Courtall, and Mr. Freeman in each hand: Gatty and Ariana seeing Courtall and Freeman shrick and—

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey-day! I told you they were a couple of
Skittish Fillies, but I never knew 'em boggle
At a man before; I'le fetch 'em agen I warrant
You, Boys.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: to Court. These are the very self-same Gowns
And Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Their surprize confirms us it must be them.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Slife, we have betray'd our selves
Very pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now am I undone to all intents and purposes,
For they will innocently discover all to my Lady,
And she will have no mercy.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Dan, Dan, Da ra, Dan, &c.
Avoid my presence, the very sight of that face
Makes me more impotent then an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Dear Sir Oliver!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Forbear your conjugal clippings,
I will have a Wench, thou shalt fetch me a
Wench, Sentry.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Can you be so inhumane to my dear Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Peace, Envy, or I will have thee executed
For petty Treason; thy skin flay'd off, stuff'd and
Hung up in my Hall in the Country, as a
Terrour to my whole Family.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: What Crime can deserve this horrid
Punishment?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I'le tell thee, Ned: 'twas my Fortune
T'other day to have an Intrigue with a Tinker's
Wife in the Country, and this malitious Slut
Betray'd the very Ditch where we us'd to
Make our assignations, to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: She deserves your anger indeed, Sir Oliver:
But be not so unkind to your vertuous Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Thou do'st not know her, Franck; I have
Had a design to break her heart ever since the
First month that I had her, and 'tis so tough,
That I have not yet crack'd one string on't.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: You are too unmerciful, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hang her, Ned, by wicked Policy she
Would usurp my Empire, and in her heart is a
Very Pharaoh; for every night she's a putting
Me upon making Brick without straw.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I cannot see a vertuous Lady so afflicted,
Without offering her some consolation:
Dear Madam, is it not as I told you?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: The Fates could not have been more
Propitious, and I shall not be wanting to the
Furthering of our mutual happiness.

div.stage: Enter Sir Joslin, with Ariana and Gatty in each hand, dancing and singing.

lg.head: CATCH.
lg.l: This is sly and pretty,
And this is wild and witty;
If either stay'd
Till she dy'd a Maid,
I faith 'twould be great pity.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Here they are, Boys, i'faith, and now little
Ioslin's a man of his word. Heuk! Sly-girl and
Mad-cap, to 'em, to 'em, to 'em, Boys, Alou!
sp.stage: Flings 'em to Courtall and Freeman, who kiss their hands.
sp.l: What's yonder, your Lady in tears, Brother Cockwood?
Come, come, I'le make up all breaches.
sp.stage: He sings—And we'll all be merry and frolick.
sp.l: Fy, fy, though man and wife are seldom in good
Humour alone, there are few want the discretion
To dissemble it in Company.

div.stage: Sir Joslin, Sir Oliver, and Lady stand talking together.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I knew we should surprize you, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Faith I thought this Conjuring to be but
A meer Jest till now, and could not believe the
Astrological Rascal had been so skilful.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: How exactly he describ'd 'em, and how
Punctual he was in his directions to apprehend 'em!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Then you have been with a Conjurer,
Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: You cannot blame us, Ladies, the loss of
Our hearts was so considerable, that it may well
Excuse the indirect means we took to find out
The pretty Thieves that stole 'em.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Did not I tell you what men of business
These were, Sister?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I vow I innocently believ'd they had some
Pre-engagement to a Scrivener or a Surgeon,
And wish'd 'em so well, that I am sorry
To find 'em so perfidious.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why, we have kept our Oaths, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: You are much beholding to Providence.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: But we are more, Sister; for had we once
Been deluded into an opinion they had been
Faithful, who knows into what inconveniences
That errour might have drawn us?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Why should you be so unreasonable, Ladies,
To expect that from us, we should scarce
Have hop'd for from you? fy, fy, the keeping
Of ones word is a thing below the honour
Of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: A poor shift! fit only to uphold the
Reputation of a paultry Citizen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, come, all will be well agen,
I warrant you, Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: These are insupportable injuries, but I will
Bear 'em with an invincible patience, and to morrow
Make him dearly sensible how unworthy he has been.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: To morrow my Brother Cockwood will
Be another man—So, Boys, and how do you like
The flesh and blood of the Jollies—Heuk, Sly-
Girl—and Mad-cap, Hey—come, come, you have
Heard them exercise their tongues a while; now
You shall see them ply their feet a little: this is
A clean Limb'd wench, and has neither spavin,
Splinter, nor Wind-gall; tune her a Jig, and play't
Roundly, you shall see her bounce it away like a
Nimble Frigot before a fresh gale—Hey, methinks I
See her under Sail already.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey my little Mad-cap—here's a Girl of
The true breed of the Jollies, i'faith—But hark you,
Hark you, a Consultation, Gentlemen—Bear up,
Brother Cockwood, a little: what think you,
If we pack these idle Huswives to bed now,
And retire into a room by our selves, and have
A merry Catch, and a Bottle or two of the
Best, and perfect the good work we have
So unanimously carry'd on to day?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: A most admirable Intrigue—tan, dan,
Da, ra, dan; come, come, march to your several
Quarters: go, we have sent for a civil person or two,
And are resolv'd to fornicate in private.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: This is a barbarous return of
All my kindness.

sp.speaker: Free. Cour.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Hark you! hark you! Ladys do not harbour
Too ill an opinion of us, for faith, when you have
Had a little more experience of the world, you'le
Find we are no such abominable Rascals.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: We shall be so charitable to think no worse
Of you, than we do of all Mankind for your
Sakes, only that you are perjur'd, perfidious,
Inconstant, ingrateful.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay, nay, that's enough in all conscience Ladys,
And now you are sensible what a shameful thing
It is to break ones word, I hope you 'le be more
Careful to keep yours to morrow.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Invent an Oath, and let it be so horrid—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Nay, nay, it is too late for raillery, i'faith, Ladys.

sp.speaker: Gatty. Aria.
sp.l: Well, your Servant then.

sp.speaker: Free. Cour.
sp.l: Your Servant, Ladys.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Now the Enemy's march'd out—

sp.speaker: Sir Iosl.
sp.l: Then the Castle's our own Boys—Hey.

lg.l: And here and there I had her,
And every where I had her,
Her toy was such, that every touch
Would make a Lover madder.

sp.speaker: Free. Cour.
sp.l: Hey brave Sir Ioslin!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.l: Ah my dear little witty Ioslin, let me
Hug thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioslin.
sp.l: Strike up you obstreperous Rascals, and
March along before us.

div.trailer: The end of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
The New-Exchange.
div.stage: Mrs. Trinckit sitting in a Shop, people passing by as in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trinc.
sp.l: WHat d'ye buy? what d'ye lack, Gentlemen?
Gloves, Ribbons, and Essences; Ribbons,
Gloves, and Essences?

sp.speaker: Mr. Courtall!
sp.l: I thought you had a quarrel
To the Change, and were resolv'd we should never
See you here again.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your unkindness indeed, Mrs. Trincket, had
Been enough to make a man banish himself
For ever.

sp.speaker: Trinc.
sp.l: Look you, yonder comes fine Mrs. Gazet, thither
You intended your visit, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Mr. Courtall! your Servant.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your Servant, Mrs. Gazet.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: This happiness was only meant to
Mrs. Trinckit, had it not been my good Fortune
To pass by, by chance, I should have lost
My share on't.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: This is too cruel, Mrs. Gazet, when all the
Unkindness is on your side, to rallie your Servant
Thus.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I vow this tedious absence of yours made
Me believe you intended to try an Experiment
On my poor heart, to discover that hidden secret,
How long a despairing Lover may languish
Without the sight of the party.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: You are always very pleasant on this
Subject, Mrs. Gazet.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And have not you reason to be so too?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Yes, you hear the good news.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: What good news?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: How well this dissembling becomes you!
But now I think better on't, it cannot
Concern you, you are more a Gentleman, than
To have an amour last longer than an Easter
Term with a Country Lady; and yet there
Are some I see as well in the Country as in
The City, that have a pretty way of Huswifing
A Lover, and can spin an intrigue out a great
Deal farther, than others are willing to do.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: What pretty art have they, good Mrs. Gazet?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: When Tradesmen see themselves in an ill
Condition, and are afraid of breaking, can they do
Better than to take in a good substantial
Partner, to help to carry on their trading?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Sure you have been at Riddle me, riddle me,
Lately, you are so wondrous witty.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And yet I believe my Lady Cockwood is so
Haughty, she had rather give over the vanity of an
Intrigue, than take in a couple of young
Handsome Kinswomen to help to maintain it.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I knew it would out at last; indeed it is the
Principle of most good women that love Gaming,
When they begin to grow a little out of play
Themselves, to make an interest in some
Young Gamester or other, in hopes to rook
A favour now and then: but you are quite out
In your policy, my Lady Cockwood is none of
These, I assure you—
Heark you, Mrs. Gazet, you must needs bestir
Your self a little for me this morning, or else
Heaven have mercy on a poor sinner.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I hope this wicked woman has no design
Upon your body already: alas! I pity your
Tender conscience.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I have always made thee my Confident, and
Now I come to thee as to a faithful Councellour.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: State your Case.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Why, this ravenous Kite is upon wing already,
Is fetching a little compass, and will be
Here within this half hour to swoop me
Away.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: And you would have me your Scar-Crow?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Something of that there is in't; she is still
Your Customer.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I have furnish'd her and the young Ladys with
A few fashionable toyes since they came
To Town, to keep 'um in countenance at a
Play, or in the Park.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I would have thee go immediately to the
Young Ladies, and by some device or other
Intice 'em hither.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I came just now from taking measure of 'em
For a couple of Handkerchiefs.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: How unlucky's this!

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: They were calling for their Hoods and Scarfs,
And are coming hither to lay out a little Money
In Ribbons and Essences: I have recommended
Them to Mrs. Trinckits Shop here.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: This falls out more luckily than what I had
Contriv'd my self, or could have done; for here
Will they be busie just before the Door, where
We have made our appointment: but if this
Long-wing'd Devil should chance to truss me
Before they come.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I will only step up and give some directions
To my Maid, about a little bus'ness that is in
Haste, and come down again and watch her; if you
Are snap'd, I'le be with you presently, and rescue
You I warrant you, or at least stay you 'till
More company come: she dares not force you
Away in my sight; she knows I am great with
Sir Oliver, and as malitious a Devil as the best
Of 'em—your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Freeman! 'tis well you are come.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Well! what Counter-plot? what hopes of
Dis-appointing the old, and of seeing the young
Ladies? I am ready to receive your Orders.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Faith, things are not so well contriv'd as I
Could have wish'd 'em, and yet I hope by
The help of Mrs. Gazet to keep my word,

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay, now I know what tool thou hast made
Choice of, I make no question but the bus'ness
Will go well forward; but I am afraid
This last unlucky bus'ness has so distasted
These young Trouts, they will not be so easily
Tickl'd as they might have been.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Never fear it; whatsoever women say, I am sure
They seldom think the worse of a man, for
Running at all, 'tis a sign of youth and high
Mettal, and makes them rather piquee, who shall
Tame him: that which troubles me most, is, we
Lost the hopes of variety, and a single intrigue
In Love is as dull as a single Plot in a Play,
And will tire a Lover worse, than t'other does
An Audience.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: We cannot be long without some under-plots
In this Town, let this be our main design,
And if we are any thing fortunate in our contrivance,
We shall make it a pleasant Comedy.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Leave all things to me, and hope the best:
Be gone, for I expect their coming immediately;
Walk a turn or two above, or fool a while
With pretty Mrs. Anvill, and scent your Eye-brows
And Perriwig with a little Essence of Oranges,
Or Jessimine; and when you see us all together
At Mrs. Gazets Shop, put in as it were by chance:
I protest yonder comes the old Haggard, to your
Post quickly: 'sdeath, where's Gazet and these
Young Ladies now
O Madam, I have waited here at least an hour, and
Time seems very tedious, when it delays so great
A happiness as you bring with you.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I vow, Sir, I did but stay to give Sir Oliver
His due correction for those unseemly injuries
He did me last night. Is your Coach ready?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Yes, Madam: but how will you dispose of
Your Maid?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: My Maid! for Heavens sake, what do you
Mean, Sir? do I ever use to go abroad without her?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: 'Tis upon no design, Madam, I speak it, I
Assure you; but my Glass-Coach broke last night,
And I was forc'd to bring my Chariot, which can hold
But two.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: O Heaven! you must excuse me, dear Sir,
For I shall deny my self the sweetest recreations
In the world, rather than yield to any thing that
May bring a blemish upon my spotless Honour.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Madam.
Your Servant, Mr. Courtall.

sp.speaker: Lady. and Cour.
sp.l: Your Servant, Mrs. Gazet.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: I am extream glad to see your Ladiship here,
I intended to send my Maid to your Lodgings
This Afternoon, Madam, to tell you I have a
Parcel of new Lace come in, the prettiest Patterns
That ever were seen; for I am very desirous so
Good a Customer as your Ladiship should see 'em
First, and have your choice.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I am much beholding to you, Mrs. Gazet,
I was newly come into the Exchange, and intended
To call at your Shop before I went home.

div.stage: Enter Ariana and Gatty, Gazet goes to 'em.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, here are your Cousins too! now there
Is no hope left for a poor unfortunate
Lover to comfort himself withall.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Will Fate never be more propitious?

sp.speaker: Aria. Gatty.
sp.l: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I am newly come into the Exchange, and
By chance met with Mr. Courtall here, who will needs
Give himself the trouble, to play the Gallant, and
Wait upon me.

sp.speaker: Gatty.
sp.l: Does your Ladiship come to buy?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: A few trifles; Mrs. Gazet says she has a
Parcel of very fine new Laces, shall we go look
Upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: We will only fancy a suit of Knots or two
At this Shop, and buy a little Essence, and wait
Upon your Ladiship immediately.

sp.speaker: Gatt.
sp.l: Mrs. Gazet, you are skill'd in the fashion, pray
Let our choice have your approbation.

div.stage: All go to the Shop to look upon Ware, but Courtall and La. Cockwood.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Most gladly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, Madam, if you had made no Ceremony,
But stept into the Coach presently, we had escap'd this
Mischief.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: My over-tenderness of my honour, has
Blasted all my hopes of happiness.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: To be thus unluckily surpriz'd in the height
Of all our expectation, leaves me no patience.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Moderate your passion a little, Sir, I may
Yet find out a way.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Oh 'tis impossible, Madam, never think on't
Now you have been seen with me; to leave 'em upon
Any pretence will be so suspitious, that my concern
For your honour will make me so feverish and
Disordered, that I shall lose the taste of all the
Happiness you give me.

sp.speaker: La. Coc.
sp.l: Methinks you are too scrupulous, heroick Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Besides the concerns I have for you, Madam,
You know the obligations I have to Sir Oliver,
And what professions of friendship there are on
Both sides; and to be thought perfidious and ingrateful,
What an affliction would that be to a generous spirit!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Must we then unfortunately part thus?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Now I have better thought on't, that is not
Absolutely necessary neither.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: These words revive my dying joys,
Dear Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I will by and by, when I see it most convenient,
Beg the favour of your Ladiship, and your
Young Kinswomen, to accept of a Treat and a
A Fiddle; you make some little difficulty at
First, but upon earnest perswasion comply, and
Use your interest to make the young Ladys
Do so too: your company will secure their
Reputations, and their company take off from
You all suspition.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: The natural inclination they have to be
Jigging, will make them very ready to comply:
But what advantage can this be to our
Happiness, dear Sir?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Why, first, Madam, if the young Ladies, or
Mrs. Gazet, have any doubts upon their surprizing
Us together, our joining company will clear 'em
All; next, we shall have some satisfaction
In being an afternoon together, though we enjoy
Not that full freedom we so passionately
Desire.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Very good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: But then lastly, Madam, we gain an opportunity
To contrive another appointment to morrow,
Which may restore us unto all those joys
We have been so unfortunately disappointed
Of to day.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: This is a very prevailing Argument
Indeed; but since Sir Oliver believes I have
Conceiv'd so desperate a sorrow, 'tis fit we
Should keep this from his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Are the young Ladies secret?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: They have the good Principles not
To betray themselves, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Then 'tis but going to a house that is
Not haunted by the Company, and we are secure,
And now I think on't, the Bear in Drury-lane is
The fittest place for our purpose.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I know your Honour, dear Sir, and
Submit to your discretion—
Have you gratifi'd your Fancies, Cousins?

div.stage: To them Ariana, Gatty, and Gazet from the Shop.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: We are ready to wait upon you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I never saw colours better mingled.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: How lively they set off one another, and
How they adde to the complexion!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Mr. Courtall, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, let me have the Honour
To wait upon you and these young Ladies,
Till I see you in your Coach.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your friendship to Sir Oliver would
Engage you in an unnecessary trouble.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Let not an idle Ceremony take you from
Your serious bus'ness, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I should rather have expected to have seen
You, Sir, walking in Westminster-Hall, watching
To make a Match at Tennis, or waiting to
Dine with a Parliament-man, then to meet
You in such an idle place as the Exchange is.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Methinks, Ladies, you are well
Acquainted with me upon the first Visit.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: We received your Character before, you
Know, Sir, in the Mulberry-Garden upon Oath.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: aside. 'Sdeath, what shall I do?
Now out comes all my Roguery.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Yet I am apt to believe, Sister, that was
Some malicious Fellow that wilfully perjur'd
Himself, on purpose to make us have an
Ill opinion of this worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Some rash men would be apt enough
To enquire him out, and cut his throat, Ladies,
But I heartily forgive him whosoever he was;
For on my conscience 'twas not so much out
Of malice to me, as out of love to you he did it.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: He might imagine Mr. Courtall was his Rival.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Very likely, Mrs. Gazet.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Whosoever he was, he was an unworthy
Fellow I warrant him; Mr. Courtall is known
To be a Person of Worth and Honour.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: We took him for an idle Fellow, Madam,
And gave but very little credit to what he said.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Twas very obliging, Lady, to believe
Nothing to the disadvantage of a stranger—
What a couple of young Devils are these?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Since you are willing to give
Your self this trouble.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I ought to do my Duty, Madam.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Ariana and Gatty.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: How he blush'd, and hung down his head!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: A little more had put him as much out
Of countenance, as a Country Clown is
When he ventures to complement
His Attourny's Daughter.

div.head: SCENE.
Sir Oliver's Dining-Room.
div.stage: Enter Sir Joslin and Servant severally.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: How now old Boy! where's my
Brother Cockwood to day?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He desires to be in private, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Why? what's the matter, man?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: This is a day of Humiliation, Sir,
With him for last nights transgression.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: I have bus'ness of consequence to impart
To him, and must and will speak with him—
So, ho! Brother Cockwood!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver
sp.l: without. Who's that, my Brother Iolly?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: The same, the same, come away, Boy.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver
sp.l: without. For some secret reasons
I desire to be in private, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: I have such a design on foot as would
Draw Diogenes out of his Tub to follow it;
Therefore I say, come away, come away.
sp.stage: Sir Oliver entring in a Night-Gown and Slippers.
sp.l: There is such a strange
Temptation in thy voice,
Never stir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: What in thy Gown and Slippers yet! why,
Brother, I have bespoke Dinner, and engag'd
Mr. Rake-hell, the little smart Gentleman I have
Often promis'd thee to make thee acquainted
Withal, to bring a whole Bevy of Damsels
In Sky, and Pink, and Flame-colour'd Taffeta's.
Come, come, dress thee quickly, there's to be
Madam Rampant, a Girl that shines, and will drink
At such a rate, she's a Mistress for Alexander, were
He alive agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: How unluckily this falls out! Thomas,
What Cloaths have I to put on?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: None but your Penitential Suit,
Sir, all the rest are secur'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Oh unspeakable misfortune! that I
Should be in disgrace with my Lady now!

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, come, never talk of Cloaths,
Put on any thing, thou hast a person and a
Mine will bear it out bravely.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Nay, I know my behaviour will show
I am a Gentleman; but yet the Ladies
Will look scurvily upon me, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: That's a Jest i'faith! he that has Terra firma

lg.l: In the Country, may appear in any thing before 'em.
For he that would have a Wench kind,
Ne're smugs up himself like a Ninny;
But plainly tells her his mind,
And tickles her first with a Guinny.

sp.l: Hay Boy—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I vow thou hast such a bewitching
Way with thee!

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: How lovely will the Ladies look when
They have a Beer-glass in their hands!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I now have a huge mind to venture;
But if this should come to my Lady's knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: I have bespoke Dinner at the Bear, the
Privat'st place in Town: there will be
No Spies to betray us, if Thomas be but secret,
I dare warrant thee, Brother Cockwood.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I have always found Thomas very
Faithful; but faith 'tis too unkind, considering
How tenderly my Lady loves me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Fy, fy, a man, and kept so much under
Correction by a Busk and a Fan!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Nay, I am in my Nature as valiant
As any man, when once I set out; but i'faith I
Cannot but think how my dear Lady will be
Concern'd when she comes home and misses me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: A Pox upon these Qualms.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, thou hast seduc'd me;
But I shall look so untowardly.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Again art thou at it? in, in, and make
All the haste that may be, Rake-hell and the
Ladies will be there before us else.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, thou art an errant Devil—hey—
For the Lady's, Brother Iolly.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey for the Lady's, Brother Cockwood.

div.head: SCENE III.
The Bear.
div.stage: Without. Ho Francis, Humphry, show a Room there!
Enter Court. Free. Lady Cockwood, Aria. Gatty and Sentry.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, be not so full of apprehension;
There is no fear that this should come to
Sir Oliver's knowledge.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I were ruin'd if it shou'd, Sir! Dear, how
I tremble! I never was in one of these houses before.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: This is a Bait for the young Ladies to
Swallow; she has been in most of the Eating-
Houses about Town, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Oh Francis!

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: Your Worship's welcome, Sir; but I
Must needs desire you to walk into the next
Room, for this is bespoke.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Mr Courtall, did not you say, this
Place was private?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I warrant you, Madam. What
Company dines here, Francis?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: A couple of Country Knights, Sir Ioslin
Iolly and Sir Oliver Cockwood, very honest Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Combination to undo me!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Peace, Madam, or you'l betray
Your self to the Waiter.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I am distracted! Sentry, did not I
Command thee to secure all Sir Oliver's Cloaths,
And leave nothing for him to put on, but his
Penitential Suit, that I might be sure he
Could not stir abroad to day?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I obey'd you in every thing, Madam; but I
Have often told you this Sir Ioslin is a wicked Seducer.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: If my Uncle sees us, Sister, what
Will he think of us?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We come but to wait upon her Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You need not fear, you Chickens are
Secure under the wings of that old Hen.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Is there to be no body, Francis,
But Sir Oliver and Sir Ioslin?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: Faith, Sir, I was enjoyn'd secrecy; but
You have an absolute power over me: coming
Lately out of the Country, where there is but
Little variety, they have a design to solace
Themselves with a fresh Girl or two, as I
Understand the business.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh Sentry! Sir Oliver disloyal!
My misfortunes come too thick upon me.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.l: aside. Now is she afraid of being
Disappointed on all hands.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I know not what to do, Mr. Courtall,
I would not be surpriz'd here my self, and yet
I would prevent Sir Oliver from prosecuting
His wicked and perfidious intentions.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Now shall we have admirable sport,
What with her fear and jealousie.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I lay my life she routs the Wenches.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: I must needs desire you to step into the next
Room; Sir Ioslin and Sir Oliver are below already.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I have not power to move a foot.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: We will consider what is to be done
Within, Madam.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, come; I have a
Design in my head which shall secure you, surprize
Sir Oliver, and free you from all your fears.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: It cannot be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Never fear it: Francis, you may owne
Mr. Freeman and I are in the house, if they ask for us;
But not a word of these Ladies, as you tender
The wearing of your Ears.

div.stage: Enter Sir Joslin, Sir Oliver, and Waiter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, Brother Cockwood, prithee be brisk.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I shall disgrace my self for ever, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Pox upon care, never droop like a Cock
In moulting time; thou art Spark enough in all
Conscience.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: But my heart begins to fail me
When I think of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: What, more Qualms yet?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, I will be couragious: but it is not
Necessary these Strangers should know this is
My Penitential Suit, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: They shall not, they shall not. Hark
You old Boy, is the meat provided? is the Wine
And Ice come? and are the melodious Rascalss
At hand I spoke for?

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: Every thing will be in a readiness, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: If Mr. Rake-hell, with a Coach full or two
Of Vizard-masks and silk Petticoats, call at the
Door, usher 'em up to the place of execution.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: You shall be obey'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Ho, here's my little Rake-hell come!
Brother Cockwood, let me commend this ingenious
Gentleman to your acquaintance; he is a Knight
Of the Industry, has many admirable qualities,
I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I am very glad; Sir, of this opportunity
To know you.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: I am happy, Sir, if you esteem me your
Servant. Hark you, Sir Ioslin, is this Sir
Oliver Cockwood in earnest?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: In very good earnest I assure you; he is
A little fantastical now and then, and dresses
Himself up in an odd fashion: but that's all one
Among Friends, my little Rake-hell.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Where are the Damsels you talk'd of,
Brother Iolly? I hope Mr. Rake-hell has not forgot 'em.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: They are arming for the ran-counter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: What, tricking and trimming?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Even so, and will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: They need not make themselves so
Full of Temptation; my Brother Iolly and I can
Be wicked enough without it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: The truth is, my little Rake-hell, we are
Both mighty men at Arms, and thou shalt see us
Charge anon to the terrour of the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Methinks that Dress Sir Oliver is a little
Too rustical for a man of your capacity.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I have an odd humour, Sir, now and
Then; but I have wherewithal at home to
Be as spruce as any man,

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Your Perriwig is too scandalous, Sir
Oliver, your black Cap and Border is never
Wore but by a Fidler or a Waiter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Prithee, my little Rake-hell, do not put my
Brother Cockwood out of conceit of himself;
Methinks your Calot is a pretty Ornament, and
Makes a man look both Polite and Politick.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: I will allow you, 'tis a grave ware, and fit
For men of bus'ness, that are every moment bending
Of their brows, and scratching of their heads, every
Project would claw out another Perriwig; but a
Lover had better appear before his Mistress with a
Bald Pate: 'twill make the Ladies apprehend a savour,
Stop their Noses, and avoid you: 'Slife, Love in a
Cap is more ridiculous then Love in a Tub, or Love
In a Pipkin.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I must confess your whole head is
Now in fashion; but there was a time when
Your Calot was not so despicable.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Here's a Perruque, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: A very good one.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: A very good one? 'tis the best in England.
Pray, Sir Ioslin, take him in your hand, and draw
A Comb through him, there is not such
Another Frizz in Europe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: 'Tis a very fine one indeed.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Pray, Sir Oliver, do me the favour to
Grace it on your head a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: To oblige you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: You never wore any thing became you half
So well in all your life before.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Why, you never saw him in your life before.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: That's all one, Sir, I know 'tis impossible.
Here's a Beaver, Sir Oliver, feel him; for fineness,
Substance, and for fashion, the Court of France
Never saw a better; I have bred him but a
Fortnight, and have him at command already.
Clap him on boldly, never Hat took the fore-
Cock and the hind-cock at one motion so naturally.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
