sp.l: I think you have a mind to make a
Spark of me before I see the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Now you have the meen of a true Cavalier,
And with one look may make a Lady kind, and
A Hector humble: and since I nam'd a Hector,
Here's a Sword, Sir: Sa, sa, sa, try him, Sir Ioslin,
Put him to't, cut through the staple, run him
Through the door, beat him to the Hilts, if he
Breaks, you shall have liberty to break my Pate,
And pay me never a Groat of the ten for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: 'Tis a very pretty Weapon indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: The Hilt is true French-wrought, and
Doree by the best Workman in France. This Sword
And this Castor, with an embroider'd Button and
Loop, which I have to vary him upon occasion,
Were sent me out of France for a Token by my elder
Brother, that went over with a handsom Equipage,
To take the pleasure of this Champagne.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Have you a mind to sell these things, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: That is below a Gentleman; yet if a person
Of Honour or a particular friend, such as I esteem
You, Sir Oliver, take at any time a fancy to a Band,
A Cravat, a Velvet Coat, a Vest, a Ring, a Flajolet,
Or any other little Toy I have about me, I am
Good-natur'd, and may be easily perswaded
To play the Fool upon good terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Worthy Mr. Freeman!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Honest Frank, how cam'st thou to
Find us out, man?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: By meer chance, Sir; Ned Courtall is without
Writing a Letter, and I came in to know whether
You had any particular engagements, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: We resolv'd to be in private; but
You are men without exception.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Methinks you intended to be in private
Indeed, Sir Oliver. 'Sdeath, what disguise have
You got on? are you grown grave since last
Night, and come to sin incognito?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hark you in your Ear, Frank, this is
My habit of humiliation, which I always put on
The next day after I have transgressed, the better
To make my pacification with my incens'd Lady—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Mr. Freeman, your most humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Oh my little dapper Officer! are you here?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Ha, Mr. Freeman, we have bespoke all the
Jovial Entertainment that a merry Wag can wish
For, good Meat, good Wine, and a wholesom
Wench or two; for the digestion, we shall have
Madam Rampant, the glory of the Town, the
Brightest she that shines, or else my little Rake-hell
Is not a man of his word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: I warrant you she comes, Sir Ioslin.

lg.l: And if she comes, she shall not scape,
If twenty pounds will win her;
Her very Eye commits a Rape,
'Tis such a tempting sinner.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Well said, Sir Ioslin, I see you hold up still,
And bate not an Ace of your good humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Courtall!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Bless me, Sir Oliver, what are you going
To act a Droll? how the people would throng
About you, if you were but mounted on a
Few Deal-boards in Covent-Garden now!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hark you, Ned, this is the Badge of my
Lady's indignation for my last night's offence; do
Not insult over a poor sober man in affliction.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Come, come, send home for your Cloaths;
I hear you are to have Ladies, and you are not
To learn at these years, how absolutely necessary
A rich Vest and a Perruque are to a man that aims
At their favours.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: A Pox on't, Ned, my Lady's gone abroad
In a damn'd jealous melancholy humour, and
Has commanded her Woman to secure 'em.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Under Lock and Key?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Ay, Ay, man, 'tis usual in these cases, out
Of pure Love in hopes to reclaim me, and to
Keep me from doing my self an injury
By drinking two days together.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: What a loving Lady 'tis!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: There are Sots that would think themselves
Happy in such a Lady, Ned; but to a true bred
Gentleman all lawful solace is abomination.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Mr. Courtall, your most humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Oh! my little Knight of the Industry, I am
Glad to see you in such good Company.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Courtall, hark you, are the Masking-habits
Which you sent to borrow at the Play-house come yet?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Yes, and the Ladies are almost dress'd:
This design will adde much to our mirth, and give
Us the benefit of their Meat, Wine, and Musick
For our Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Twas luckily thought of.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hark, the Musick comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey, Boys—let 'em enter, let 'em enter.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: An't please your Worships, there is a Mask
Of Ladies without, that desire to have the
Freedom to come in and dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey! Boys—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Did you bid 'em come 'en Masquerade, Mr.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: No; but Rampant is a mad Wench, she
Was half a dozen times a mumming in private
Company last Shrove-tide, and I lay my life she has
Put 'em all upon this Frolick.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: They are mettled Girls, I warrant them,
Sir Ioslin, let 'em be what they will.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Let 'em enter, let 'em enter, ha Boys—

div.stage: Enter Musick and the Ladies in an Antick, and then they take out, my Lady Cockwood Sir Oliver, the young Ladies Courtal and Freeman, and Sentry Sir Joslin, and dance a set Dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Oh my little Rogue! have I got thee?
How I will turn and winde, and fegue thy body!

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Mettle on all sides, mettle on all sides,
I'faith; how swimmingly would this pretty little
Ambling Filly carry a man of my body!

lg.l: She's so bonny and brisk,
How she'd carvet and frisk,
If a man were once mounted upon her!
Let me have but a leap
Where 'tis wholesom and cheap,
And a fig for your Person of Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: 'Tis true, little Ioslin, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: They have warm'd us, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Now am I as rampant as a Lyon, Ned,
And could love as vigorously as a Sea-man that
Is newly landed after an East-India Voyage.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Take my advice, Sir Oliver, do not in your
Rage deprive your self of your only hope
Of an accommodation with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I had rather have a perpetual civil War,
Then purchase Peace at such a dishonourable rate.
A poor Fidler, after he has been three days persecuted
At a Country-wedding, takes more delight in scraping
Upon his old squeeking Fiddle, then I do in fumbling
On that domestick Instrument of mine.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Be not so bitter, Sir Oliver, on your
Own dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I was married to her when I was young,
Ned, with a design to be baulk'd, as they tye Whelps
To the Bell-weather; where I have been so butted,
'Twere enough to fright me, were I not pure
Mettle, from ever running at sheep again.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: That's no sure rule, Sir Oliver; for a
Wife's a dish, of which if a man once surfeit, he shall
Have a better stomach to all others ever after.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: What a shape is here, Ned! so exact and
Tempting, 'twould perswade a man to be an
Implicite sinner, and take her face upon credit.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, Brother Cockwood, let us get 'em
To lay aside these masking Fopperies, and then
We'll fegue 'em in earnest: give us a Bottle, Waiter.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Not before Dinner, good Sir Ioslin—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Lady, though I have out of Drollery
Put my self into this contemptible Dress at present,
I am a Gentleman, and a man of Courage, as you
Shall find anon by my brisk behaviour.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Sir Ioslin! Sir Oliver! these are none of our
Ladies, they are just come to the door in a Coach, and
Have sent for me down to wait upon 'em up to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey—Boys, more Game, more Game!
Fetch 'em up, fetch 'em up.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Why, what a day of Sport will here be,
Ned?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: They shall all have fair Play, Boys.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: And we will match our selves, and make
A Prize on't, Ned Courtall and I, against Frank
Freeman and you Brother Iolly, and Rake-hell
Shall be Judge for Gloves and silk Stockings, to be
Bestow'd as the Conquerour shall fancy.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Court. Free.
sp.l: A match, a match.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hey, Boys!
Oh Heavens! my dear Lady!
Help, help!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: What's here? Sentry and my Lady!
'Sdeath, what a condition am I in now, Brother Iolly!
You have brought me into this Premunire: for
Heavens sake run down quickly, and send the Rogue
And Whores away. Help, help! oh help! dear
Madam, sweet Lady!
sp.stage: Ex. Sir Joslin, Sir Oliver kneels down by her.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh she's gone, she's gone!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Give her more Air.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Fetch a glass of cold Water, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Dear Madam speak, sweet Madam speak.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Out upon thee for a vile Hypocrite! thou
Art the wicked Author of all this; who but such a
Reprobate, such an obdurate sinner as thou art,
Could go about to abuse so sweet a Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Dear Sentry, do not stab me with thy words,
But stab me with thy Bodkin rather, that I may here
Dye a Sacrifice at her feet, for all my disloyal actions.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: No live, live, to be a reproach and a shame
To all rebellious Husbands; ah, that she had but
My Heart! but thou hast bewitch'd her affections;
Thou shouldst then dearly smart for this abominable
Treason.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: So, now she begins to come to her self.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Set her more upright, and bend her a little
Forward.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Unfortunate Woman! let me go,
Why do you hold me? wou'd I had a Dagger at
My Heart, to punish it for loving that ungrateful man.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Dear Madam, were I but worthy
Of your pity and belief.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Peace, peace, perfidious man, I am too
Tame and foolish—were I every day at the Plays,
The Park, and Mulberry-Garden, with a kind look
Secretly to indulge the unlawful passion of some
Young Gallant; or did I associate my self with the
Gaming Madams, and were every afternoon at my
Lady Briefes and my Lady Meanwells at Vmbre and
Quebas, pretending ill luck to borrow money of a
Friend, and then pretending good luck to excuse the
Plenty to a Husband, my suspicious demeanour had
Deserv'd this; but I who out of a scrupulous
Tenderness to my Honour, and to comply with thy
Base Jealousie, have deny'd my self all those blameless
Recreations, which a vertuous Lady might enjoy,
To be thus inhumanely revil'd in my own person, and
Thus unreasonably rob'd and abus'd in thine too!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Sure she will take up anon, or crack
Her mind, or else the Devil's in't.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Do not stay and torment me with thy
Sight; go, graceless Wretch, follow thy treacherous
Resolutions, do, and waste that poor stock of comfort
Which I should have at home, upon those your ravenous
Cormorants below: I feel my passion begin to
Swell again.

div.stage: She has a little fit agen.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now will she get an absolute dominion over
Him, and all this will be my Plague in the end.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: running up and down. Ned. Courtall, Frank Freeman, Cousin
Ariana, and dear Cousin Gatty, for
Heavens sake joyn all, and moderate her passion—
Ah Sentry! forbear thy unjust reproaches, take pity
On thy Master! thou hast a great influence over her,
And I have always been mindful of thy favours.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You do not deserve the least compassion,
Nor wou'd I speak a good word for you, but that
I know for all this, 'twill be acceptable to my poor
Lady. Dear Madam, do but look up a little, Sir
Oliver lyes at your feet an humble Penitent.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: How bitterly he weeps! how sadly he sighs!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I dare say he counterfeited his sin, and is
Real in his Repentance.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Compose your self a little, pray, Madam;
All this was meer Raillery, a way of talk, which
Sir Oliver being well bred, has learned among
The gay people of the Town.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: If you did but know, Madam, what an odious
Thing it is to be thought to love a Wife in good
Company, you wou'd easily forgive him.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: No, no, 'twas the mild correction which
I gave him for his insolent behaviour last night, that
Has encourag'd him agen thus to insult over my
Affections.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Come, come, Sir Oliver, out with your
Bosom-secret, and clear all things to your Lady;
Is it not as we have said?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Or may I never have the happiness to be
In her good grace agen; and as for the Harlots,
Dear Madam, here is Ned Courtall and Frank Freeman,
That have often seen me in company of the
Wicked; let 'em speak, if they ever knew me tempted
To a disloyal action in their lives.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: On my conscience, Madam, I may more
Safely swear, that Sir Oliver has been constant to
Your Ladiship, then that a Girl of twelve years old
Has her Maiden-head this warm and ripening Age.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Here's my Brother Iolly too can witness
The loyalty of my Heart, and that I did not intend
Any treasonable practice against your Ladiship
In the least.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Unless feguing 'em with a Beer-glass be
Included in the Statute. Come, Mr. Courtall, to
Satisfie my Lady, and put her in a little good humour,
Let us sing the Catch I taught you yesterday, that was
Made by a Country Vicar on my Brother Cockwood.
And me.

lg.l: Love and Wenching are Toys,
Fit to please beardless Boys,
Th' are sports we hate worse then a Leaguer;
When we visit a Miss,
We still brag how we kiss,
But 'tis with a Bottle we fegue her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, come, Madam, let all things be
Forgot; Dinner is ready, the Cloath is laid in the
Next Room, let us in and be merry; there was no
Harm meant as I am true little Ioslin.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Sir Oliver knows I can't be angry with
Him, though he plays the naughty man thus; but
Why, my Dear, wou'd y' expose your self in this
Ridiculous habit, to the censure of both our Honours?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Indeed I was to blame to be over-
Perswaded; I intended dutifully to retire into the
Pantry, and there civilly to divert my self at Back-
Gammon with the Butler.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Faith, I must ev'n owne, the fault was
Mine, I intic'd him hither, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: How the Devil, Ned, came they to find
Us out here!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: No Blood-hound draws so sure as a jealous Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I am afraid Thomas has been unfaithful:
Prithee, Ned, speak to my Lady, that there may be
A perfect understanding between us, and that Sentry
May be sent home for my Cloaths, that I may no
Longer wear the marks of her displeasure.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Let me alone, Sir Oliver.
sp.stage: He goes to my Lady Cockwood.
sp.l: How do you find your self, Madam, after
This violent Passion?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: This has been a lucky adventure,
Mr. Courtall; now am I absolute Mistress of
My own conduct for a time.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Then shall I be a happy man, Madam: I
Knew this wou'd be the consequence of all, and
Yet could not I forbear the project.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: How didst thou shuffle away Rake-hell
And the Lady's Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: I have appointed 'em to meet us at six a
Clock at the new Spring-Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Then will we yet, in spight of the Stars
That have cross'd us, be in Conjunction with
Madam Rampant, Brother.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, Dinner is on the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Ha! Sly-girl and Mad-cap, I'le enter
You, i'faith; since you have found the way
To the Bear, I'le fegue you.

lg.l: When we visit a Miss,
We still brag how we kiss;
But 'tis with a Bottle we fegue her.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: A Lady cannot be too jealous of her Servants
Love, this faithless and inconstant Age:
His amorous Carriage to that prating Girl to day,
Though he pretends it was to blind Sir Oliver,
I fear will prove a certain sign of his revolted
Heart; the Letters I have counterfeited in these Girls
Name will clear all; if he accept of that appointment,
And refuses mine, I need not any longer doubt.
Sentry, have the Letters
And message been deliver'd, as I directed?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Punctually, Madam; I knew they were to be
Found at the latter end of a Play, I sent a Porter
First with the Letter to Mr. Courtall, who
Was at the Kings-house, he sent for him out
By the Door-keeper, and deliver'd it into
His own hands.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Did you keep on your Vizard, that
The Fellow might not know how to describe you?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I did, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: And how did he receive it?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Like a Traytor to all goodness, with
All the signs of Joy imaginable.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Be not angry, Sentry, 'tis as my heart
Wisht it: what did you do with the Letter to
Mr. Freeman? for I thought fit to deceive 'em both,
To make my Policy less suspicious to Courtall.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: The Porter found him at the Dukes-house,
Madam, and deliver'd it with like care.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: After the Letters were deliver'd, Madam,
I went my self to the Play-house, and sent in
For Mr. Courtall, who came out to me immediately;
I told him your Ladiship presented your humble
Service to him, and that Sir Oliver was going
Into the City with Sir Ioslin, to visit his Brother
Cockwood, and that it wou'd add much more
To your Ladiships happiness, if he wou'd be pleas'd
To meet you in Grayes-Inn-walks this lovely evening.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: And how did he entertain the motion?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Bless me! I tremble still to think upon it!
I cou'd not have imagin'd he had been so wicked;
He counterfeited the greatest passion, railed at
His Fate, and swore a thousand horrid Oaths,
That since he came into the Play-house he had
Notice of a business that concerned both his
Honour and Fortune; and that he was an undone
Man, if he did not go about it presently;
Pray'd me to desire your Ladiship to excuse
Him this Evening, and that to morrow he wou'd
Be wholly at your devotion.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! he little thinks how
Much he has oblig'd me.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I had much ado to forbear upbraiding
Him with his ingratitude to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Poor Sentry! be not concern'd for
Me, I have conquer'd my affection, and thou
Shalt find it is not Jealousie has been my Councellour
In this. Go, let our Hoods and Masks be ready,
That I may surprize Courtall, and make the
Best advantage of this lucky opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I obey you, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: How am I fill'd with indignation!
To find my person and my passion both despis'd,
And what is more, so much precious time
Fool'd away in fruitless expectation: I wou'd
Poyson my face, so I might be reveng'd on
This ingrateful Villain.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: My Dearest!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: My Dearest Dear! prithee do
Not go into the City to night.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: My Brother Iolly is gone before,
And I am to call him at Councellour Trott's
Chamber in the Temple.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Well, if you did but know the fear
I have upon me when you are absent, you would
Not seek occasions to be from me thus.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv
sp.l: Let me comfort thee with a kiss;
What should'st thou be afraid of?

sp.speaker: La Cock.
sp.l: I cannot but believe that every Woman
That sees thee must be in love with thee, as I am;
Do not blame my Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I protest I wou'd refuse a Countess
Rather then abuse thee, poor Heart.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: And then you are so desperate upon
The least occasion, I shou'd have acquainted
You else with something that concerns your Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: My Honour! you ought in Duty to do it.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Nay, I knew how passionate you wou'd
Be presently; therefore you shall never know it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Do not leave me in doubt, I shall
Suspect every one I look upon; I will kill a
Common Councel-man or two before I come
Back, if you do not tell me.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Dear, how I tremble! will you
Promise me you will not quarrel then? if you tender
My life and happiness, I am sure you will not.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I will bear any thing rather then be
An Enemy to thy quiet, my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I cou'd wish Mr. Courtall a man of better
Principles, because I know you love him, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Why, what has he done?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I always treated him with great respects,
Out of my regard to your friendship; but he, like
An impudent man as he is, to day misconstruing
My Civility, in most unseemly language,
Made a foul attempt upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Death, and Hell, and Furies, I will
Have my Pumps, and long Sword!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh, I shall faint! did not you promise
Me you wou'd not be so rash?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, I will not kill him, for fear of
Murdering thee, my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You may decline your friendship, and
By your coldness give him no incouragement
To visit our Family.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I think thy advice the best for this once
Indeed; for it is not fit to publish such a bus'nes:
But if he shou'd be ever tempting or attempting,
Let me know it, prithee, my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: If you moderate your self according
To my directions now, I shall never conceal
Any thing from you, that may increase your
Just opinion of my conjugal fidelity.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Was ever man bless'd with such
A vertuous Lady! yet cannot I forbear going a
Ranging agen. Now must I to the Spring-Garden
To meet my Brother Iolly and Madam Rampant.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Prithee, be so good to think how
Melancholy I spend my time here; for I have
Joy in no Company but thine, and let that
Bring thee home a little sooner.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Thou hast been so kind in this discovery,
That I am loth to leave thee.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I wish you had not been engag'd so far.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Ay, that's it: farewel, my vertuous Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Farewel, my Dearest Dear. I know
He has not courage enough to question Courtall;
But this will make him hate him, encrease his
Confidence of me, and justifie my banishing that
False Fellow our house; it is not fit a man that
Has abus'd my Love, shou'd come hither, and pry
Into my actions: besides this will make his
Access more difficult to that wanton Baggage.
sp.stage: Enter Ariana and Gatty with their Hoods and Masks.
sp.l: Whither are you going, Cousins?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: To take the Air upon the Water, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: And for Variety, to walk a turn or two
In the new Spring-Garden.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I heard you were gone abroad
With Mr. Courtall and Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: For Heaven's sake, why shou'd your Ladiship
Have such an ill opinion of us?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: The truth is, before I saw you, I believ'd
It meerly the vanity of that prating man; Mr.
Courtall told Mrs. Gazet this morning, that you
Were so well acquainted already, that you
Wou'd meet him and Mr. Freeman any where,
And that you had promis'd 'em to receive
And make appointment by Letters.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Oh impudent man!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Now you see the consequence, Sister,
Of our rambling; they have rais'd this false story
From our innocent fooling with 'em in the
Mulberry-Garden last night.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I cou'd almost foreswear ever speaking
To a man agen.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Was Mr. Courtall in the Mulberry-Garden
last night?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: And did he speak to you?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: There pass'd a little harmless Raillery
Betwixt us; but you amaze me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: I cou'd not imagine any man could
Be thus unworthy.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: He has quite lost my good opinion
Too: in Duty to Sir Oliver, I have hitherto show'd
Him some countenance; but I shall hate him
Hereafter for your sakes. But I detain you from
Your Recreations, Cousins.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We are very much oblig'd to your
Ladiship for this timely notice.

sp.speaker: Aria. Gat.
sp.l: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your Servant, Cousins—in the
Mulberry-Garden last night! when I sat languishing,
And vainly expecting him at home: this has
Incens'd me so, that I could kill him. I am glad
These Girls are gone to the Spring-Garden, it
Helps my design; the Letters I have counterfeited,
Have appointed Courtall and Freeman to meet
Them there, they will produce 'em, and confirm
All I have said: I will daily poyson these Girls
With such lyes as shall make their quarrel to
Courtall irreconcileable, and render Freeman
Only suspected; for I wou'd not have him
Thought equally guilty: He secretly began
To make an address to meat the Bear, and
This breach shall give him an opportunity
To pursue it.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Here are your things, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: That's well: Oh Sentry! I shall once
More be happy; for now Mr. Courtall has given
Me an occasion, that I may without ingratitude
Check his unlawful passion, and free my self
From the trouble of an Intrigue, that gives me
Every day such fearful apprehensions of my honour.

div.head: SCENE II.
New Spring-Garden.
div.stage: Enter Sir Joslin, Rake-hell, and Waiter.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.l: Will you be pleas'd to walk into
An Arbour, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: By and by, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: I wonder Sir Oliver is not come yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Nay, he will not fail I warrant thee,
Boy; but what's the matter with thy Nose,
My little Rake-hell?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: A foolish accident; jesting at the Fleece
This afternoon, I mistook my man a little, a dull
Rogue that could not understand Raillery,
Made a sudden Repertee with a Quart-pot,
Sir Ioslin.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Why didst not thou stick him to the
Wall, my little Rake-hell?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: The truth is, Sir Ioslin; he deserv'd it;
But look you, in case of a doubtful wound,
I am unwilling to give my friends too often the
Trouble to bail me; and if it shou'd be
Mortal, you know a younger Brother has
Not wherewithal to rebate the edge of a
Witness, and mollifie the hearts of a Jury.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: This is very prudently consider'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: 'Tis time to be wise, Sir; my Courage has
Almost run me out of a considerable Annuity.
When I liv'd first about this Town, I agreed
With a Surgeon for twenty pounds a Quarter▪
To cure me of all the Knocks, Bruises, and
Green Wounds I shou'd receive, and in one half
Year the poor Fellow beg'd me to be releas'd▪
Of his bargain, and swore I wou'd undo him▪
Else in Lint and Balsom.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Ho! here's my Brother Cockwood come—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I, Brother Iolly, I have kept my word,
You see; but 'tis a barbarous thing to abuse my
Lady, I have had such a proof of her Vertue,
I will tell thee all anon.
But where's Madam Rampant, and the rest of
The Ladies, Mr. Rake-hell?

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Faith, Sir, being disappointed at noon,
They were unwilling any more to set a certainty
At hazard: 'tis Term-time, and they have
Severally betook themselves, some to their
Chamber-practice, and others to the Places
Of Publick Pleading.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Faith, Brother Iolly, let us ev'n go into
An Arbour, and then fegue Mr. Rake-hell.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: With all my heart, wou'd we had
Madam Rampant.

lg.l: She's as frolick and free,
As her Lovers dare be,
Never aw'd by a foolish Punctilio;
She'l not start from her place,
Though thou nam'st a black Ace,
And will drink a Beer-glass to Spudilio.

sp.l: Hey, Boys! Come, come, come! let's in,
And delay our sport no longer.
sp.stage: Exit singing, She'l not start from her, &c.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Freeman!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Courtall, what the Devil's the matter with
Thee? I have observ'd thee prying up and down
The Walks like a Citizen's Wife that has dropt
Her Holy-day Pocket-handkercher.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: What unlucky Devil has brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I believe a better natur'd Devil then yours,
Courtall, if a Leveret be better meat then an old
Puss, that has been cours'd by most of the young
Fellows of her country: I am not working my
Brain for a Counter-plot, a disappointment is not
My bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: You are mistaken, Freeman: prithee be
Gone, and leave me the Garden to my self, or I
Shall grow as testy as an old Fowler that is put
By his shoot, after he has crept half a mile
Upon his belly.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Prithee be thou gone, or I shall take it as
Unkindly as a Chymist wou'd, if thou should'st
Kick down his Limbeck in the very minute
That he look'd for projection.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Come, come, you must yield, Freeman,
Your bus'ness cannot be of such consequence as mine.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: If ever thou hadst a bus'ness of such
Consequence in thy life as mine is, I will condescend
To be made incapable of affairs presently.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Why, I have an appointment made me,
Man, without my seeking, by a Woman for
Whom I wou'd have mortgag'd my whole
Estate to have had her abroad but to break
A Cheese-cake.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And I have an appointment made me without
My seeking too, by such a she, that I will break the
Whole ten Commandments, rather then
Disappoint her of her breaking one.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Come, you do but jest, Freeman, a forsaken
Mistress cou'd not be more malicious then thou
Art: prithee be gone.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Prithee do thou be gone.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Sdeath! the sight of thee will scare
My Woman for ever.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Sdeath! the sight of thee will make my
Woman believe me the falsest Villain breathing.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: We shall stand fooling till we are both
Undone, and I know not how to help it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Let us proceed honestly like Friends,
Discover the truth of things to one another, and
If we cannot reconcile our bus'ness, we will
Draw Cuts, and part fairly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I do not like that way; for talk is only
Allowable at the latter end of an Intrigue, and
Shou'd never be us'd at the beginning of an
Amour, for fear of frighting a young Lady from
Her good intentions—yet I care not, though I
Read the Letter, but I will conceal the name.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I have a Letter too, and am content
To do the same.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: reads. Sir, in sending you this Letter, I
Proceed against the modesty of our Sex—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, this begins just like my Letter.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Do you read on then—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: reads. But let not the good opinion I have
Conceiv'd of you, make you too severe in your
Censuring of me—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Word for word.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Now do you read agen.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: reads. If you give your self the trouble to be
Walking in the new Spring-Garden this Evening, I
Will meet you there, and tell you a secret, which
I have reason to fear, because it comes to your
Knowledge by my means, will you make you hate
Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Verbatim my Letter, Hey-day!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Prithee lets compare the Hands.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, the Hand's the same.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I hope the Name is not the same too—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: If it be, we are finely jilted, faith.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I long to be undeceiv'd; prithee do
Thou show first, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: No—but both together, if you will.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Gatty—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: The little Rogues are masculine in their
Proceeedings, and have made one another
Confidents in their Love.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: But I do not like this altogether so well,
Frank; I wish they had appointed us several
Places: for though 'tis evident they have
Trusted one another with the bargain, no
Woman ever seals before Witness.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Prithee how didst thou escape the snares
Of the old Devil this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: With much ado; Sentry had set me; if her
Ladiship had got me into her clutches, there
Had been no getting off without a Rescue,
Or paying down the money; for she
Always arrests upon Execution.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You made a handsom lye to her Woman.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: For all this, I know she's angry; for she
Thinks nothing a just Excuse in these cases,
Though it were to save the forfeit of a mans
Estate, or reprieve the life of her own
Natural Brother.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Faith, thou hast not done altogether like
A Gentleman with her; thou should'st fast thy
Self up to a stomach now and then, to oblige
Her; if there were nothing in it, but the hearty
Welcome, methinks 'twere enough to make thee
Bear sometimes with the homeliness of the Fare.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I know not what I might do in a Camp,
Where there were no other Woman; but I shall
Hardly in this Town, where there is such plenty,
Forbear good meat, to get my self an
Appetite to Horse-flesh.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This is rather an aversion in thee, then any
Real fault in the Woman; if this lucky bus'ness
Had not fallen out, I intended with your good
Leave to have out-bid you for her Ladiships
Favour.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I should never have consented to that, Frank;
Though I am a little resty at present, I am not such
A Jade, but I should strain if another rid against
Me; I have e're now lik'd nothing in a Woman
That I have lov'd at last in spight only,
Because another had a mind to her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Yonder are a couple of Vizards tripping
Towards us.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Tis they, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: We need not divide, since they come together.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I was a little afraid when we compar'd
Letters, they had put a trick upon us; but now I
Am confirm'd they are mighty honest.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: We cannot avoid 'em.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Let us dissemble our knowledge of their
Bus'ness a little, and then take 'em down in
The height of their assurance.

sp.speaker: Court. Free.
sp.l: Your Servant, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: I perceive it is as impossible, Gentlemen,
To walk without you, as without our shadows;
Never were poor Women so haunted by the
Ghosts of their self-murdered Lovers.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: If it should be our good Fortunes to have
You in Love with us, we will take care you
Shall not grow desperate, and leave the
World in an ill humour.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: If you shou'd, certainly your Ghosts
Would be very malicious.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Twere pity you should have your Curtains
Drawn in the dead of the night, and your pleasing
Slumbers interrupted by any thing but flesh
And blood, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Shall we walk a turn?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: By your selves, if you please.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Our Company may put a constraint upon
You; for I find you daily hover about these
Gardens, as a Kite does about a back-side,
Watching an opportunity to catch up the Poultry.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Wo be to the Daughter or Wife of some
Merchant-Taylor, or poor Felt-maker now;
For you seldom row to Fox-hall without
Some such Plot against the City.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You wrong us, Ladies, our bus'ness has
Happily succeeded, since we have the
Honour to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: You could not expect to see us here.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Your true Lover, Madam, when he misses
His Mistress, is as restless as a Spaniel that has
Lost his Master; he ranges up and down
The plays, the Park, and all the Gardens, and
Never stays long, but where he has the
Happiness to see her.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I suppose your Mistress, Mr. Courtall, is
Always the last Woman you are acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Do not think, Madam, I have that false
Measure of my acquaintance, which Poets have
Of their Verses, always to think the last best,
Though I esteem you so, in justice to your merit.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Or if you do not love her best, you always
Love to talk of her most; as a barren Coxcomb
That wants discourse, is ever entertaining
Company out of the last Book he read in.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Now you accuse me most unjustly, Madam;
Who the Devil, that has common sense, will go a
Birding with a Clack in his Cap?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Nay, we do not blame you, Gentlemen,
Every one in their way; a Huntsman talks of his
Dogs, a Falconer of his Hawks▪ a Jocky of
His Horse, and a Gallant of his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Without the allowance of this Vanity, an
Amour would soon grow as dull as Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Whatsoever you say, Ladies, I cannot
Believe you think us men of such abominable
Principles.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: For my part, I have ever held it as ingrateful
To boast of the favours of a Mistress, as to deny
The Courtesies of a Friend.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: A Friend that bravely ventures his life in▪
The field to serve me, deserves but equally with▪
A Mistress that kindly exposes her Honour to
Oblige me, especially when she does it as▪
Generously too, and with as little Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And I would no more betray the Honour
Of such a Woman, then I would the life of a
Man that shou'd rob on purpose to supply me.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We believe you men of Honour, and know
It is below you to talk of any Woman that deserves it.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: You are so generous, you seldom insult▪
After a Victory.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: And so vain, that you always triumph
Before it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Sdeath! what's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Though you find us so kind, Mr. Courtall,
Pray do not tell Mrs. Gazet to morrow, that
We came hither on purpose this Evening▪
To meet you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I wou'd as soon print it, and fee a Fellow
To post it up with the Play-bills.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: You have repos'd a great deal of confidence
In her, for all you pretend this ill opinion
Of her secrecy now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I never trusted her with the name of a
Mistress, that I should be jealous of; if I saw her
Receive fruit, and go out of the Play-House
with a Stranger.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: For ought as I see, we are infinitely
Oblig'd to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible to be insensible of so
Much goodness, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: What goodness, pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Come, come, give over this Raillery.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: You are so ridiculously unworthy, that 'twere
A folly to reprove you with a serious look.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: On my conscience, your heart begins to
Fail you now we are coming to the point, as a
Young Fellow's that was never in the field before.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: You begin to amaze me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Since you your self sent the challenge,
You must not in Honour flye off now.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Challenge! Oh Heavens! this confirms
All: were I a man, I would kill thee for the
Injuries thou hast already done me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: to Aria. Let not your suspicion of my
Unkindness make you thus scrupulous; was ever
City ill treated, that surrendred without Assault
Or Summons?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Dear Sister, what ill Spirit brought us
Hither? I never met with so much impudence
In my life.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: aside. Hey Jilts! they are as good at it
Already, as the old one i'faith.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Come, Ladies, you have exercis'd your
Wit enough; you wou'd not venture Letters
Of such consequence for a jest only.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Letters! bless me, what will this come to?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: To that none of us shall have cause to
Repent I hope, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Let us flye 'em, Sister, they are Devils,
And not men, they could never be so
Malicious else.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your Servant, Cousins.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: starting. Ho my Lady Cockwood! my ears
Are grown an inch already.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: My Lady! she'll think this an appointment,
Sister.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This is Madam Matchiavil, I suspect, Courtall.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis her Plot doubtless: now am I
As much out of countenance, as I should be if Sir Oliver
Should take me making bold with her Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Do not let me discompose you,
I can walk alone, Cousins.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Are you so uncharitable, Madam, to think
We have any business with 'em?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: It has been our ill Fortune to meet 'em
Here, and nothing could be so lucky as your
Coming, Madam, to free us from 'em.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: They have abus'd us in the grossest manner.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Counterfeited Letters under our Hands.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Never trouble your selves, Cousins, I
Have heard this is a common practice with such
Unworthy men: did they not threaten to divulge
Them, and defame you to the World?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We cannot believe they intend any thing
Less, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Doubtless, they had such a mean opinion
Of your Wit and Honour, that they thought to
Fright you to a base compliance with their
Wicked purposes.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: I hate the very sight of 'em.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I could almost wish my self a disease, to
Breathe infection upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Very pretty! we have carried on our designs
Very luckily against these young Ladies.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: We have lost their good opinion for ever.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I know not whether their folly or their
Impudence be greater, they are not worth your▪
Anger, they are only fit to be laught at, and despis'd.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: A very fine old Devil this!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Mr. Freeman, this is not like a Gentleman,
To affront a couple of young Ladies thus; but I
Cannot blame you so much, you are in a manner a
Stranger to our Family: but I wonder how that
Base man can look me in the face, considering
How civilly he has been treated at our house.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: The truth is, Madam, I am a Rascal; but I
Fear you have contributed to the making me so:
Be not as unmerciful as the Devil is to a poor sinner.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Did you ever see the like? never trust
Me, if he has not the confidence to make my
Vertuous Lady accessary to his wickedness.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Ay Sentry! 'tis a miracle if my Honour
Escapes, considering the access which his greatness
With Sir Oliver has given him daily to me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Faith, Ladies, we did not counterfeit these
Letters, we are abus'd as well as you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I receiv'd mine from a Porter at the King's
Play-house, and I will show it you, that you may
See if you know the Hand.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Sentry, are you sure they never saw
Any of your Writing?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Sdeath! I am so discompos'd, I know
Not where I have put it.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh Madam! now I remember my self,
Mrs. Gatty help'd me once to indite a Letter
To my Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Forgetful Wench! then I am undone.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Oh here it is—Hey, who's here?

div.stage: As he has the Letter in hand, enter Sir Joslin, Sir Oliver, and Rakehell, all drunk, with Musick.

lg.l: She's no Mistress of mine
That drinks not her Wine,
Or frowns at my friends drinking motions;
If my Heart thou would'st gain,
Drink thy Bottle of Champaigne.
'Twill serve thee for Paint and Love-potions.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Who's here? Courtall, in my Lady's
Company! I'le dispatch him presently;
Help me, Brother Iolly.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: For Heavens sake, Sir Oliver!

sp.speaker: Courtall
sp.l: drawing. What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I'le teach you more manners, then
To make your attempts on my Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: & Sent. Oh! Murder! Murder!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Save my dear Sir Oliver, Oh my
Dear Sir Oliver!

div.stage: The young Ladies shriek and run out, they all draw to part 'em, they fight off the Stage, she shrieks and runs out.

div.head: SCENE I.
Sir Oliver's Dining-Room.
div.stage: Enter Lady Cockwood, Table, and Carpet.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I Did not think he had been so desperate in
His Drink; if they had kill'd one another,
I had then been reveng'd, and freed from all my
Fears—Sentry, your carelessness and
Forgetfulness some time or other will undo me;
Had not Sir Oliver and Sir Ioslin came so luckily
Into the Garden, the Letters had been discover'd,
And my Honour left to the mercy of a false man,
And two young fleering Girls: did you speak
To Mr. Freeman unperceiv'd in the Hurry?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I did, Madam, and he promis'd me to disengag
Himself as soon as possibly he could, and wait
Upon your Ladiship with all secrecy.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I have some reason to believe him
A man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Methinks indeed his very look, Madam,
Speaks him to be much more a Gentleman
Then Mr. Courtall; but I was unwilling before
Now to let your Ladiship know my opinion, for
Fear of offending your inclinations.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I hope by his means to get these Letters
Into my own hands, and so prevent the inconveniencies
They may bring upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I wonder, Madam, what should be Sir
Oliver's Quarrel to Mr. Courtall.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You know how apt he is to be suspicious
In his Drink; 'tis very likely he thought Mr. Courtall
Betray'd him at the Bear to day.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n he be not jealous of your
Ladiship, finding you abroad so unexpectedly; if
He be, we shall have a sad hand of him when he
Comes home, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I should have apprehended it much
My self, Sentry, if his drunkenness had not unadvisedly
Ingag'd him in his quarrel; as soon as he grows a
Little sober, I am sure his fear will bring him
Home, and make him apply himself to me with
All humility and kindness; for he is ever under▪
Hand fain to use my interest and discretion to
Make friends to compound these businesses,
Or to get an order for the securing his
Person and his Honour.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I believe verily, Mr. Courtall wou'd have
Been so rude to have kill'd him, if Mr. Freeman and
The rest had not civilly interpos'd their Weapons.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Heavens forbid! though he be a wicked
Man, I am oblig'd in Duty to love him: whither
Did my Cousins go after we came home, Sentry?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: They are at the next door, Madam,
Laughing and playing at Lantre-lou, with my old
Lady Love-youth and her Daughters.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I hope they will not come home then
To interrupt my affairs with Mr. Freeman:
Hark! some body knocks, it may be him,
Run down quickly.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I fly, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Now if he has a real inclination for my
Person, I'le give him a handsome opportunity
To reveal it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Your Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh Mr. Freeman! this unlucky accident
Has rob'd me of all my quiet; I am almost distracted
With thinking of the danger Sir Oliver's dear
Life is in.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You need not fear, Madam, all things will
Be reconcil'd again to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: You wou'd not blame my Lady's
Apprehensions, did you but know the
Tenderness of her affections.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Mr. Courtall is a false and merciless man.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He has always own'd a great respect for
Your Ladiship, and I never heard him mention
You with the least dishonour.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: He cannot without injuring the Truth,
Heaven knows my innocence: I hope you did
Not let him know, Sir, of your coming hither.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I shou'd never merit the happiness to wait
Upon you again, had I so abus'd this extraordinary
Favour, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: If I have done any thing unbeseeming
My Honour, I hope you will be just, Sir, and
Impute it to my fear; I know no man so proper
To compose this unfortunate difference as
Your self, and if a Lady's tears and prayers
Have power to move you to compassion, I
Know you will imploy your utmost endeavour
To preserve me, my dear Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Do not, Madam, afflict your self so much,
I dare ingage my life, his Life and Honour shall
Be both secure.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You are truly noble, Sir; I was so
Distracted with my fears, that I cannot well
Remember how we parted at the Spring-Garden.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: We all divided, Madam: after your Ladiship
And the young Ladies were gone together, Sir
Oliver, Sir Ioslin, and the Company with them,
Took one Boat, and Mr. Courtall and I another.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Then I need not apprehend their
Meeting again to night.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You need not, Madam; I left Mr. Courtall in
His Chamber, wondring what shou'd make
Sir Oliver draw upon him, and fretting and
Fuming about the Trick that was put upon
Us with the Letters to day.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh! I had almost forgot my self; I
Assure you, Sir, those Letters were sent by one
That has no inclination to be an enemy of yours.
Some body knocks.
If it be Sir Oliver, I am undone, he will hate me
Mortally, if he does but suspect I use any secret
Means to hinder him from justifying his
Reputation honourably to the World.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh Madam! here is Mr. Courtall below in
The Entry, discharging a Coach-man; I told
Him your Ladiship was busie, but he wou'd
Not hear me, and I find, do what I can,
He will come up.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I wou'd not willingly suspect you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I have deceiv'd him, Madam, in my coming
Hither, and am as unwilling he shou'd find me
Here, as you can be.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: He will not believe my innocent business
With you, but will raise a new Scandal on my
Honour, and publish it to the whole Town.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Let him step into the Closet, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Quick, Sir, quick, I beseech you, I will
Send him away again immediately.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Mr. Courtall! have you no sense of▪
Honour nor modesty left? after so many injuries,
To come into our House, and without my
Approbation rudely press upon my
Retirement thus?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, hear my business.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Thy business is maliciously to pursue
My ruine; thou comest with a base design to have
Sir Oliver catch thee here, and destroy the
Only happiness I have.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I come, Madam, to beg your pardon for
The fault I did unwillingly commit, and to know
Of you the reason of Sir Oliver's Quarrel to me.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Thy guilty conscience is able to tell
Thee that, vain and ungrateful man!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I am innocent, Madam, of all things that
May offend him; and I am sure, if you wou'd
But hear me, I shou'd remove the Justice
Of your Quarrel too.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You are mistaken, Sir, if you think
I am concern'd for your going to the Spring-Garden
This Evening; My Quarrel is the same with
Sir Oliver, and is so just, that thou deserv'st to
Be poyson'd for what thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, let me know my fault.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I blush to think upon't: Sir Oliver, since
We came from the Bear, has heard something
Thou hast said concerning me; but what it is,
I cou'd not get him to discover: he told me 'twas
Enough for me to know he was satisfi'd of
My innocence.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: This is meer passion, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: This is the usual revenge of such base
Men as thou art, when they cannot compass
Their ends, with their venomous tongues
To blast the Honour of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: This is a sudden alteration, Madam; within
These few hours you had a kinder opinion of me.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: 'Tis no wonder you brag of favours
Behind my back, that have the impudence to
Upbraid me with kindness to my face; dost
Thou think I cou'd ever have a good thought of
Thee, whom I have always found so treacherous
In thy friendship to Sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh Madam! here is Sir Oliver come home.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: O Heavens! I shall be believ'd guilty
Now, and he will kill us both.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I warrant you, Madam, I'le defend your life.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh! there will be Murder, Murder;
For Heavens sake, Sir, hide your self in some
Corner or other.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I'le step into that Closet, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Hold, hold, Sir, by no means; his Pipes
And his Tobacco-box lye there, and he
Always goes in to fetch 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your malice will soon be at an end:
Heaven knows what will be the fatal consequence
Of your being found here.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Madam, let him creep under the Table,
The Carpet is long enough to hide him.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Have you good Nature enough to
Save the Life and Reputation of a Lady?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Any thing to oblige you, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: running to the Closet. Be sure you do not stir, Sir,
Whatsoever happens.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Not unless he pulls me out by the Ears.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Good! he thinks my Lady speaks to him.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: My dear Sir Oliver—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I am unworthy of this kindness, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Nay, I intend to chide you for your▪
Naughtiness anon; but I cannot chuse but hug,
Thee, and kiss thee a little first; I was afraid.
I shou'd never have had thee alive within▪
These arms agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Your goodness does so encrease my
Shame, I know not what to say, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Well, I am glad I have thee safe at
Home, I will lock thee up above in my Chamber,
And will not so much as trust thee down stairs,
Till there be an end of this quarrel.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I was so little my self, I knew not what
I did, else I had not expos'd my person to so
Much danger before thy face.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: 'Twas cruelly done, Sir, knowing the killing
Concerns my Lady has for you.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: If Mr. Courtall had kill'd thee, I was
Resolv'd not to survive thee; but before I had
Dy'd, I wou'd have dearly reveng'd thy Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: As soon as I had recollected my self a
Little, I cou'd not rest till I came home to give thee
This satisfaction, that I will do nothing without
Thy advice and approbation, my Dear: I know
Thy Love makes thy life depend upon mine,
And it is unreasonable I shou'd upon my own
Rash head hazard that, though it be for the
Justification of thy Honour.
U'ds me I have let fall a China-Orange that
Was recommended to me for one of the best
That came over this year; 'Slife light the Candle,
Sentry, 'tis run under the Table.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh, I am not well!

div.stage: Sentry takes up the Candle, there is a great knocking at the door, she runs away with the Candle.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! who's that that knocks
So hastily?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Why, Sentry! bring back the Candle;
Are you mad to leave us in the dark, and your
Lady not well? how is it, my Dear?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: For Heavens sake run after her, Sir Oliver,
Snatch the Candle out of her hand, and teach
Her more manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: I will, my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: What shall I do? was ever Woman
So unfortunate in the management of affairs!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: What will become of me now?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: It must be so, I had better trust my
Honour to the mercy of them two, then be
Betray'd to my Husband: Mr. Courtall, give
Me your hand quickly, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Here, here, Madam, what's to be done now?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I will put you into the Closet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: He'll be coming in for his Tobacco-box
And Pipes.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Never fear that, Sir.
sp.stage: Freeman out of the Closet door.
sp.l: Now shall I be discover'd; pox
On your honourable intrigue,
Wou'd I were safe at Giffords.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Here, here, Sir, this is the door,
Whatsoever you feel, be not frighted; for
Shou'd you make the least disturbance,
You will destroy the life, and what is more,
The Honour of an unfortunate Lady.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: So, so, if you have occasion to remove
Agen, make no Ceremony, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver, Sentry, Ariana, Gatty.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Here is the Candle, how dost thou,
My Dear?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: I cou'd not imagine, Sentry, you had
Been so ill bred, to run away, and leave your
Master and me in the dark.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I thought there had been another Candle
Upon the Table, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Good! you thought! you are always
Excusing of your carelessness; such another
Misdemeanour—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Prithee, my Dear, forgive her.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: The truth is, I ought not to be very
Angry with her at present, 'tis a good natur'd
Creature; she was so frighted, for fear of
Thy being mischief'd in the Spring-Garden,
That I verily believe she scarce knows
What she does yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Light the Candle, Sentry, that I
May look for my Orange.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: You have been at my Lady Love-youths,
Cousins, I hear.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: We have, Madam.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: She charg'd us to remember her Service to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: So, here it is, my Dear, I brought it
Home on purpose for thee.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: 'Tis a lovely Orange indeed! thank you,
My Dear; I am so discompos'd with the fright
I have had, that I wou'd fain be at rest.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Get a Candle, Sentry; will you go
To bed, my Dear?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir Oliver: 'tis late,
Cousins, you had best retire to your Chamber too.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We shall not stay long here, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Come, my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Good night, Cousins.

sp.speaker: Gat. and Aria.
sp.l: Your Servant, Madam.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Oliver, Lady Cockwood, and Sentry.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: I cannot but think of those Letters, Sister.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: That is, you cannot but think of Mr. Freeman,
Sister; I perceive he runs in thy head as much as
A new Gown uses to do in the Country, the
Night before 'tis expected from London.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: You need not talk, for I am sure the losses
Of an unlucky Gamester are not more his
Meditation, then Mr. Courtall is yours.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: He has made some slight impression on my
Memory, I confess; but I hope a night will
Wear him out agen, as it does the noise
Of a Fiddle after Dancing.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Love, like some stains, will wear out of it
Self, I know, but not in such a little time as
You talk of, Sister.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: It cannot last longer then the stain of a
Mulberry at most; the next season out that goes,
And my heart cannot be long unfruitful, sure.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Well, I cannot believe they forg'd these
Letters; what shou'd be their end?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: That you may easily guess at; but methinks
They took a very improper way to compass it.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: It looks more like the malice or Jealousie
Of a Woman, then the design of two witty men.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: If this shou'd prove a Fetch of her Ladiships
Now, that is a playing the loving Hypocrite
Above with her dear Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: How unluckily we were interrupted, when
They were going to show us the hand!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: That might have discover'd all: I have a
Small suspicion, that there has been a little
Familiarity between her Ladiship and
Mr. Courtall.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Our finding of 'em together in the Exchange,
And several passages I observ'd at the Bear, have
Almost made me of the same opinion.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Yet I wou'd fain believe the countinuance
Of it is more her desire, then his inclination:
That which makes me mistrust him most, is her
Knowing we made 'em an appointment.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: If she were jealous of Mr. Courtall, she
Wou'd not be jealous of Mr. Freeman too; they
Both pretend to have receiv'd Letters.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: There is something in it more then we are
Able to imagine; time will make it out, I hope,
To the advantage of the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: I wou'd gladly have it so; for I believe,
Shou'd they give us a just cause, we should find it
A hard task to hate them.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: How I love the Song I learnt t'other day,
Since I saw them in the Mulberry-Garden!

lg.l: To little or no purpose I spent many days,
In ranging the Park, th' Exchange, and th' Plays;
For ne' re in my rambles till now did I prove
So luckie to meet with the man I cou'd love.
Oh! how I am pleas'd when I think on this man,
That I find I must love, let me do what I can!
How long I shall love him, I can no more tell,
Then had I a Fever, when I shou'd be well.
My passion shall kill me before I will show it,
And yet I wou'd give all the world he did know it;
But oh how I sigh, when I think shou'd he woo me,
I cannot deny what I know wou'd undo me!

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Fy, Sister, thou art so wanton.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I hate to dissemble when I need not;
'Twou'd look as affected in us to be reserv'd
Now w'are alone, as for a Player to maintain
The Character she acts in the Tyring-room.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Prithee sing a good Song.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Now art thou for a melancholy Madrigal,
Compos'd by some amorous Coxcomb, who
Swears in all Companies he loves his Mistress
So well, that he wou'd not do her the injury,
Were she willing to grant him the favour,
And it may be is Sot enough to believe he
Wou'd oblige her in keeping his Oath too.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Well, I will reach thee thy Guitar out of
The Closet, to take thee off of this subject.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I'de rather be a Nun, then a Lover at
Thy rate; devotion is not able to make
Me half so serious as Love has made
Thee already.

div.stage: Aria. opens the Closet, Court. and Free. come out.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Ha, Freeman! is this your bus'ness
With a Lawyer? here's a new discovery, i'faith!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Peace, man, I will satisfie your Jealousie
Hereafter; since we have made this lucky
Discovery, let us mind the present bus'nesses.

div.stage: Court. and Free. catch the Ladies, and bring them back.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Nay, Ladies, now we have caught you,
There is no escaping till w'are come to a right
Understanding.

div.stage: Enter Lady Cock. and Sir Oliv. and Sentry.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Come, never blush, we are as loving as
You can be for your hearts, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Had it not been our good Fortunes to
Have been conceal'd here, you wou'd have
Had ill Nature enough to dissemble with
Us at least a fortnight longer.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: What's the matter with you here?
Are you mad, Cousins? bless me, Mr. Courtall
And Mr. Freeman in our house at these
Unseasonable hours?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Fetch me down my long Sword, Sentry,
I lay my life Courtall has been tempting the
Honour of the young Ladies.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh my Dear!

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: We are almost scared out of our wits;
My Sister went to reach my Guitar out of the
Closet, and found 'em both shut up there.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Come, come, this will not serve your
Turn; I am afraid you had a design secretly
To convey 'em into your Chamber: well,
I will have no more of these doings in my
Family, my Dear; Sir Ioslin shall remove
These Girls to morrow.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You injure the young Ladies, Madam;
Their surprize shews their innocence.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: If any body be to blame, it is Mrs. Sentry.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: What mean you, Sir? Heaven knows
I know no more of their being here—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Nay▪ nay, Mrs. Sentry, you need not
Be asham'd to owne the doing of a couple of
Young Gentlemen such a good office.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Do not think to put your tricks upon me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Understanding by Mrs. Sentry, Madam,
That these young Ladies wou'd very likely
Sit and talk in the Dining-room an hour before
They went to bed, of the accidents of the
Day, and being impatient to know whether
That unlucky bus'ness which happen'd in
The Spring-Garden, about the Letters, had
Quite destroy'd our hopes of gaining their
Esteem; for a small sum of money Mr. Freeman
And I obtain'd the favour of her to shut us
Up where we might over-hear 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Is this the truth, Sentry?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I humbly beg your pardon, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: A Lady's Honour is not safe, that keeps
A Servant so subject to corruption; I will turn
Her out of my Service for this.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Good! I was suspicious their bus'nesses
Had been with my Lady at first.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Now will I be in Charity with him▪
Agen, for putting this off so handsomly.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hark you my Dear, shall I forbid
Mr. Courtall my house?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh! by no means, my Dear; I had
Forgot to tell thee, since I acquainted thee with
That bus'ness, I have been discoursing with my
Lady Love-youth, and she blam'd me infinitely
For letting thee know it, and laugh'd exceedingly
At me, believing Mr. Courtall intended thee
No injury, and told me 'twas only a harmless
Gallantry, which his French breeding
Has us'd him to.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Faith, I am apt enough to believe it;
For on my conscience, he is a very honest Fellow.
Ned Courtall! how the Devil came it about
That thee and I fell to Sa, Sa, in the
Spring-Garden?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: You are best able to resolve your
Self that, Sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, the Devil take me, if I had the
Least unkindness for thee—prithee let us
Embrace and kiss, and be as good Friends
As ever we were, dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I am so reasonable, Sir Oliver, that I will
Ask no other satisfaction for the injury you have
Done me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Here's the Letter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Sister, look here, do you know this hand?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: 'Tis Sentry's.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! I shall be ruin'd yet.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: She has been the Contriver of all this mischief.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Nay, now you lay too much to her charge
In this; she was but my Lady's Secretary, I
Assure you, she has discover'd the whole
Plot to us.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Will he betray me at last?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: My Lady being in her Nature severely
Vertuous, is, it seems, offended at the innocent
Freedom you take in rambling up and down
By your selves; which made her, out of a
Tenderness to your Reputations, counterfeit
These Letters, in hopes to fright you to that
Reservedness which she approves of.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: This has almost redeem'd my opinion
Of his Honour.
Cousins, the little regard you had to the good
Counsel I gave you, puts me upon this
Business.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, what was it Mrs. Gazet
Told you concerning us?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing, Cousins: what I told
You of Mr. Courtall, was meer invention, the
Better to carry on my design for your good.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Freeman! pray what brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: A kind Summons from her Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Why did you conceal it from me?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I was afraid thy peevish Jealousie might
Have destroy'd the design I had of getting an
Opportunity to clear our selves to the
Young Ladies.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Fortune has been our friend in that
Beyond expectation.
I hope, Ladies, you are satisfi'd
Of our innocence now.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Well, had you been found guilty of the
Letters, we were resolv'd to have counterfeited
Two Contracts under your hands, and have
Suborn'd Witnesses to swear 'em.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: That had been a full revenge; for I know
You wou'd think it as great a Scandal to be
Thought to have an inclination for Marriage,
As we shou'd to be believ'd willing to take
Our freedom without it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: The more probable thing, Ladies, had
Been only to pretend a Promise; we have
Now and then courage enough to venture so far
For a valuable consideration.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: The truth is, such experienc'd Gentlemen
As you are, seldom mortgage your persons
Without it be to redeem your Estates.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Tis a mercy we have 'scap'd the mischief
So long, and are like to do Penance only for
Our own sins; most Families are a Wedding
Behind hand in the World, which makes
So many young men fool'd into Wives, to pay
Their Fathers Debts: all the happiness a
Gentleman can desire, is to live at liberty,
Till he be forc'd that way to pay his own.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Ladies, you know we are not ignorant
Of the good Intentions you have towards
Us; pray let us treat a little.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: I hope you are not in so desperate a
Condition, as to have a good opinion of
Marriage, are you?

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: 'Tis to as little purpose to treat with us
Of any thing under that, as it is for those kind
Ladies, that have oblig'd you with a valuable
Consideration, to challenge the performance
Of your promise.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Well, and how, and how, my dear Ned,
Goes the business between you and these Ladies?
Are you like to drive a Bargain?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Faith, Sir Oliver, we are about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: And cannot agree, I warrant you; they
Are for having you take a Lease for life, and you are
For being Tenants at Will, Ned, is it not so?

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: These Gentlemen have found it so convenient
Lying in Lodgings, they'l hardly venture on the
Trouble of taking a House of their own.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: A pretty Country-seat, Madam, with a
Handsom parcel of Land, and other necessaries
Belonging to't, may tempt us; but for a Town▪
Tenement that has but one poor conveniency,
We are resolv'd we'll never deal.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Hark! my Brother Iolly's come home.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Now, Gentlemen, you had best look to
Your selves, and come to an agreement with us
Quickly; for I'le lay my life, my Uncle has
Brought home a couple of fresh Chap-men,
That will out-bid you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hey Boys!

lg.l: A Catch and a Glass,
A Fiddle and a Lass,
What more wou'd an honest man have?
Hang your temperate Sot,
Who wou'd seem what he's not;
'Tis I am wise, he's but grave.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: What's here? Mr. Courtall and Mr. Freeman!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Oh man! here has been the prettiest,
The luckiest discovery on all sides! we are
All good Friends again.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Hark you Brother Cockwood, I have got
Madam Rampant; Rake-hell and she are without.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! dear Brother Iolly, send
Her away immediately, my Lady has such an aversion
To a naughty Woman, that she will swound if
She does but see her.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Faith, I was hard put to't, I wanted a
Lover, and rather then I would break my old
Wont, I dress'd up Rampant in a Suit I bought
Of Rake-hell; but since this good Company's here,
I'le send her away. My little Rake-hell, come
Hither; you see here are two powerful Rivals;
Therefore for fear of kicking, or a worse disaster,
Take Rampant with you, and be going quickly.

sp.speaker: Rake.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: You may hereafter spare your self this
Labour, Sir Ioslin; Mr. Freeman and I have vow'd
Our selves humble Servants to these Ladies.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I hope we shall have your approbation, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Nay, if you have a mind to commit
Matrimony, I'le send for a Canonical Sir shall
Dispatch you presently.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You cannot do better.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: What think you of taking us in the humour?
Consideration may be your Foe, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, I'le make you a fair
Proposition; since you have made a discovery
Of our inclinations, my Sister and I will be content
To admit you in the quality of Servants.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: And if after a months experience of your
Good behaviour, upon serious thoughts, you have
Courage enough to ingage further, we will accept
Of the Challenge, and believe you men of Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Well spoke i'faith, Girls; and is it
A match, Boys?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: If the heart of man be not very deceitful,
'Tis very likely it may be so.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: A month is a tedious time, and will be a
Dangerous tryal of our resolutions; but I
Hope we shall not repent before Marriage,
Whate're we do after.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: How stand matters between you and
Your Lady, Brother Cockwood? is there
Peace on all sides?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Perfect concord, man: I will tell
Thee all that has happen'd since I parted from
Thee, when we are alone, 'twill make thee laugh
Heartily. Never man was so happy in a
Vertuous and a loving Lady!

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Though I have led Sir Oliver astray
This day or two, I hope you will not exclude me
The Act of Oblivion, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: The nigh Relation I have to you,
And the Respect I know Sir Oliver has for you,
Makes me forget all that has pass'd, Sir; but pray
Be not the occasion of any new transgressions.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I hope, Mr. Courtall, since my endeavours
To serve you, have ruin'd me in the opinion of
My Lady, you will intercede for a reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Most willingly, Mrs. Sentry—faith, Madam,
Since things have fallen out so luckily, you must
Needs receive your Woman into favour agen.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Her Crime is unpardonable, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Upon solemn protestations, Madam, that
The Gentlemens intentions were honourable,
And having reason to believe the young Ladies
Had no aversion to their inclinations, I was
Of opinion I shou'd have been ill natur'd, if I
Had not assisted 'em in the removing those
Difficulties that delay'd their happiness.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Come, come, Girl, confess how many
Guinnys prevail'd upon your easie Nature.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: Ten, an't please you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: 'Slife, a sum able to corrupt an honest
Man in Office! faith you must forgive her,
My Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: If it be your pleasure, Sir Oliver,
I cannot but be obedient.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: If Sir Oliver, Madam, shou'd ask me to
See this Gold, all may be discover'd yet.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: If he does, I will give thee ten
Guinnys out of my Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: I shall take care to put him upon't;
'Tis fit, that I who have bore all the blame,
Shou'd have some reasonable reward for't.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I hope, Madam, you will not envy me
The happiness I am to enjoy with your
Fair Relation

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Your ingenuity and goodness, Sir,
Have made a perfect attonement for you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, what was your bus'ness
With Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Only to oblige him to endeavour a
Reconciliation between you and Sir Oliver;
For though I was resolv'd never to see your
Face agen, it was death to me to think
Your life was in danger.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: What a miraculous come off is this▪
Madam!

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: It has made me so truly sensible of
Those dangers to which an aspiring Lady
Must daily expose her Honour, that I am
Resolv'd to give over the great bus'ness of
This Town, and hereafter modestly
Confine my self to the humble Affairs
Of my own Family.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: 'Tis a very pious resolution, Madam,
And the better to confirm you in it, pray
Entertain an able Chaplain.

sp.speaker: La. Cock.
sp.l: Certainly Fortune was never before
So unkind to the Ambition of a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Come, Boys, faith we will have a
Dance before we go to bed—Sly-girl and
Mad-cap, give me your hands, that I may
Give 'em to these Gentlemen, a Parson shall
Joyn you e're long, and then you will have
Authority to dance to some purpose: Brother
Cockwood, take out your Lady, I am for Mrs. Sentry.

lg.l: We'll foot it and side it, my pretty little Miss,
And when we are aweary, we'll lye down and kiss.

sp.l: Play away, Boys.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: to Gatty. Now shall I sleep as little
Without you, as I shou'd do with you:
Madam, expectation makes me almost
As restless as Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Faith, let us dispatch this bus'ness;
Yet I never cou'd find the pleasure of waiting▪
For a Dish of Meat, when a man was heartily
Hungry.

sp.speaker: Gat.
sp.l: Marrying in this heat wou'd look as ill
As fighting in your Drink.

sp.speaker: Aria.
sp.l: And be no more a proof of Love,
Then t'other is of Valour.

sp.speaker: Sir Ios.
sp.l: Never trouble your heads further;
Since I perceive you are all agreed on the
Matter, let me alone to hasten the Ceremony:
Come, Gentlemen, lead 'em to their Chambers;
Brother Cockwood, do you shew the way
With your Lady.
Ha Mrs. Sentry!

lg.l: I gave my Love a Green-gown
I'th merry month of May,
And down she fell as wantonly,
As a Tumbler does at Play.

sp.l: Hey Boys, lead away Boys.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, my Vertuous, my Dear;
Henceforwards may our mutual Loves increase,
And when we are a bed, we'll sign the Peace.
